review_preview: Place is highly recommended for cheap and very tasty brunch. Nice small and cosy place. Not too loud. Excellent atmosphere. Mostly Spanish people.We chose for the menu with benedict eggs with avocado and chocolate cake and the  mushroom salad with goat cheese. Both were...
review_full: Place is highly recommended for cheap and very tasty brunch. Nice small and cosy place. Not too loud. Excellent atmosphere. Mostly Spanish people. We chose for the menu with benedict eggs with avocado and chocolate cake and the mushroom salad with goat cheese. Both were excellent. Mushroom salad was more filling than the eggs, although cheaper (8.5 vs 7.5). We had one with home fries and the other with hash brownies. The home fries are better. Dessert of the day was chocolate cake. It was de-li-cious!! Big coffees come with milk without asking for it, so if you like it black, mention it when you order. Will go back for sure when next in madrid

review_preview: Carmencita is currently THE place to have brunch at Madrid, and when you feel the taste of the eggs Benedict on your mouth you understand why. These delicious eggs, served either with bacon, salmon or avocato, are the star-dish, but there are other eggs options...
review_full: Carmencita is currently THE place to have brunch at Madrid, and when you feel the taste of the eggs Benedict on your mouth you understand why. These delicious eggs, served either with bacon, salmon or avocato, are the star-dish, but there are other eggs options available (rancheros, and the typical scrambled eggs with sausage and bacon on the side), and also hamburgers.  We had a mimosa and a bloody mary for drink. Both of them ok (the mimosa was made with artificial orange juice... but it costed 1€). We paid 25€ for 2 eggs benedict, 1 mimosa, 1 bloody more and 2 large cups of coffee, which is a very good value-for-money in Madrid's brunch scene. The only problem is that the place is very crowded (make sure you book your table in advance!) and the waiters, although all very nice, get a bit lost in the middle of all the fuss.

title_review: When craving an American style breakfast in Madrid….
review_preview: After awhile, "tostada con tomate" for breakfast gets boring.  I was craving Huevos Rancheros and my hubby desired some Eggs Benedict, so we decided to finally try Carmencita's Bar.  We didn't have a reservation, but got there right before it opened, and luckily there new...
review_full: After awhile, "tostada con tomate" for breakfast gets boring. I was craving Huevos Rancheros and my hubby desired some Eggs Benedict, so we decided to finally try Carmencita's Bar. We didn't have a reservation, but got there right before it opened, and luckily there new restaurant (same menu and a few doors down: La Gringa) had a table available. While not the best brunch we've ever had, it was still very good and worthy of future visits. Other items on the menu looked wonderful, so we may try lunch or early dinner here too. If going for brunch, highly recommend a reservation, because it was solidly booked and they were turning people away….seems like the locals like this place too.

review_preview: After extensive googling I came across Carmencita for Brunch. We arrived and were sad to find out weekends require reservations! However, we were welcome to sit at the bar or a high top table. The owner was INCREDIBLY sweet, she accommodated us and made smalltalk....
review_full: After extensive googling I came across Carmencita for Brunch. We arrived and were sad to find out weekends require reservations! However, we were welcome to sit at the bar or a high top table. The owner was INCREDIBLY sweet, she accommodated us and made smalltalk. Soon, we had mimosas in hand, a jug of water, and 3 seats at the bar (for about 15 minutes, before she let us know we could have a high top table).  I got the eggs benedict (one salmon, one avocado...which BTW is the way to go!!). I've never been a huge benedict fan, but after seeing someone else's plate...I had to. IT WAS INCREDIBLE. Hashbrowns were perfect and Valentina hot sauce was the perfect complement.  A friend of mine got the huevos rancheros which I didn't even get to see very much/much less try because he basically inhaled them. That good.  We got a cake for dessert which may have had the best chocolate frosting I've had in Spain so far...and rivals many American ones.  Already planning my next trip...and many to come after.

review_preview: Birthday dinner for 6 and couldn't be happier.Decor: modern eclectic, comfy but classy...however we sat on the terrace outside, just off the Calle de Serrano... balmy Madrid night, why not? Service: above and beyond. I've got 10 years of restaurant industry work under my...
review_full: Birthday dinner for 6 and couldn't be happier. Decor: modern eclectic, comfy but classy...however we sat on the terrace outside, just off the Calle de Serrano... balmy Madrid night, why not?  Service: above and beyond. I've got 10 years of restaurant industry work under my belt and I love to eat out, so I can be picky. BUT 12 years in Spain has taught me that good service is not a given ever. Therefore, when it is good, I notice and I return. From the host to the bartender to the manager, everyone was friendly and kind...and fast, no waiting ages for dishes or having food come dragging out in strange stages. Food: classic Spanish fare with modern touches. Our favorites were Torta Finca.. a very strong sheep's cheese, creamy and milky, perfectly balanced with a sweet little tomato jam; Tortilla española with truffle.. taking homey fare to sublime heights; Mollete de Pringa.. pringa is like a puree of meats and it reminds me of dancing flamenco (well in my case stumbling to flamenco) at the Feria de Sevilla...here it is taken up a notch and served with a slathering of salmorejo (gazpacho's sophisticated cousin). Would skip the albondigas de abuela (grandma's meatballs) next time--bland and chewy.  Finished with Lemon Meringue cake and I can say as a born and raised Southerner, it was divine and authentic!. All that, plus more, several bottles of wine, copas of cave and less than 40/euro a person-- great deal! Will return, a lot!

title_review: You must go if you like alcohol, brunch and value!
review_preview: I had 2 days in Madrid alone whilst my partner worked and after reading some blogs of must do's in Madrid, Carmencita Bar popped up as a brunch specialist. The place opens at midday so I took a leisurely stroll over there arriving at 12.15...
review_full: I had 2 days in Madrid alone whilst my partner worked and after reading some blogs of must do's in Madrid, Carmencita Bar popped up as a brunch specialist.  The place opens at midday so I took a leisurely stroll over there arriving at 12.15 and got a table, the atmosphere is very relaxed, waitress came to my table and gave me menus and complimentary water. First thing I notice is the price is very reasonable and in places staggeringly cheap. A Mimosa was 1 euro.... 1 EURO!!! Now I was on my own and it was 12.15pm however I could not turn down 1 euro Mimosas!  I also ordered the Bunny Plate with the complimentary side of green salad. Normally when you get eggs nowadays for brunch you get a choice or salmon, bacon or avocado. The bunny plate had all three! Three half toasted tea cakes with each of the three salmon, bacon and avocado topped with a poached egg and hollandaise sauce. This is more than enough and a reasonable 10.50 euros. Coffees are cheap too at 1.50 but I'd stick with Mimosas if I were you! Would highly recommend and in a group would be such good fun for brunch.

review_preview: The craving for Indian food was getting too much. While we like exploring new restaurants, the experience we had at Swagat lured us back. Being a Saturday evening we were  expecting a larger crowd at the restaurant. But since we eat early ( in comparison...
review_full: The craving for Indian food was getting too much. While we like exploring new restaurants, the experience we had at Swagat lured us back.  Being a Saturday evening we were expecting a larger crowd at the restaurant. But since we eat early ( in comparison to Spanish families) we were the second family entering around 8.30pm. The staff were nice and allowed us to choose the table where we would like to sit.  We chose the paapdi chaat for a starter. Then we had the chicken tikka masala, pulav and dal for mains along with a couple of tandoori rotis. I asked for the food a tad spicier compared to the previous time. While it catered to my taste, my toddler had a tough time since he is not used to it. They also offered us a palate cleanser - a mango sorbet between the appetizer and mains which was very good.  We had the house wine which is pretty good and the lime mojito (too sweet and less alcohol compared to Spain standards).  The staff are very attentive and friendly. We had a good time and will definitely return.

title_review: If you're in Madrid, do not miss this place!

They offer about 6 or 8 different types of hamburgers and they are all delicious, served with homemade fries. If you order a drink, you are served a very high quality tapa, from basic but delicious spanish tortilla to cream cheese with caramelized onions. Also, this is one of the few locations I've found in the city that serves brunch, and it is amazing! If you're in Madrid, do not miss this place!

Modern looking and inviting menu, met by a very polite waiter , my girlfriend was impressed, the starters were fantastic and everything food and drink wise is reasonably priced and high quality. My only one negative is that we ordered a couple of drinks and needed to remind the waiter both times. The mains were delicious and not small portions. I would be happy coming here as a family a group or as a romantic couple. The deserts were prompt and delicious also. A very modern restaurant serving tremendous food and not over the odds prices. Go go go. You will not be disappointed.

review_preview: We found this establishment on TripAdvisor with great reviews.  We arrived early evening and it was fairly quiet.  Decorations quite bright but lovely and authentic with fabulous ganesh statues! We all ordered dishes that we knew we liked such as Chicken Tikka, Buttter Chicken, Spinach...
review_full: We found this establishment on TripAdvisor with great reviews. We arrived early evening and it was fairly quiet. Decorations quite bright but lovely and authentic with fabulous ganesh statues! We all ordered dishes that we knew we liked such as Chicken Tikka, Buttter Chicken, Spinach Paneer and a fish curry, popadoms on the side and peshwari naan. The food was delicious, fresh, and authentic. The poppadoms were different to your usual UK variety. They had, what I think were, cumin seeds in them and had a distinctive taste, but great, the peshwari naan had what looked like sunflower seeds and small pieces of fried fruit, such as papaya on the top but tasted delicious. The spinach panner didn't look very attractive as it arrived in a dish with paneer sitting within lots of bright green sauce, not pieces of spinach as I am used to but it tasted delicious, a lot better than it looked. The staff were friendly and attentive, the only small downside that it was quite expensive, but great for the experience and a treat!

review_preview: I have been to several restaurants serving Indian food in Madrid but I think Swagat is by far the most authentic. Me and my wife decided to try Swagat after reading positive reviews and we were not dissapointed. We had samosas for starters which was...
review_full: I have been to several restaurants serving Indian food in Madrid but I think Swagat is by far the most authentic. Me and my wife decided to try Swagat after reading positive reviews and we were not dissapointed. We had samosas for starters which was quite decent. This was followed by chicken curry and garlic naan. The waiter asked us if we would like it spicy and they made it as spicy as an indian curry should be. After this we have been visiting Swagat quite regularly. My personal favourite is the rogan josh as i feel chicken dishes are relatively easy to make but preparing a good mutton curry requires real skill. The owner is usually available herself over the weekends to help with her recommendations.

review_preview: My friend and I came here for dinner the other night because I was telling her how great my first experience was with another group of people.  I forgot to do review then so made sure I did this time. The atmosphere is great  with...
review_full: My friend and I came here for dinner the other night because I was telling her how great my first experience was with another group of people. I forgot to do review then so made sure I did this time. The atmosphere is great with cute decor and staff friendly with smiles. They speak both Spanish and English which is nice which makes it less intimidating. There is a good variety of food and if you request they can also make it hotter. The service was pretty fast and food was hot and full of flavor. I want to go back now and order more. Serving sizes are perfect for the price and there is no way you are leaving hungry. I loved how the food not only smells and taste amazing but the presentation of the food is very appealing. From appetizers to main course and dessert the food just pops with flavors and plenty of choices even for someone who may be picky. If in Madrid this place is definitely worth stopping by for a meal. I really like how the staff make you feel very welcome.

title_review: Excellent Indian food in a fantastic location
review_preview: I went down to Swagat with my colleagues and friends based on reviews read on a popular website. The restaurant was located in a very nice locality close to the Velazquez metro station and city bus stops, so locating it was not too difficult. The...
review_full: I went down to Swagat with my colleagues and friends based on reviews read on a popular website. The restaurant was located in a very nice locality close to the Velazquez metro station and city bus stops, so locating it was not too difficult. The ambience of the restaurant was very welcoming with a beautiful intricate Ganapati statue and a glittering large chandelier at the entrance. The restaurant was quite spacious and could easily accomodate large groups of 16 - 20 with ease. The menu had a large number of options featuring both a-la-carte dishes and fixed meals. Initially, we were served papads (Indian crackers) with green chutney, a yogurt based sauce, tamarind chutney and a chilli based cutney. We ordered a starter dish consisting of an onion bhajji, a vegetable cutlet, a potato cutlet and a samosa. The starters were very good though a bit oily, but the taste was great, particularly the onion bhajji. For the main course, we had chana masala, paneer kadai, aloo gobhi and dal tadka with tandoori rotis. The food was well prepared and tasted great. This was followed by veg biriyani and a cucumber raita. The biriyani lacked a little salt, but was well prepared with paneer (Indian unsalted cottage cheese) and vegetables. The final tab / bill was not more than expected. The small sugar coated saunf (fennel seeds) that was served as mukhwas (mouth freshner) was very nice as well. The staff at the restaurant was extremely courteous and explained us the dishes properly and also enquired the amount of spice and hotness desired by us (we were a group on Indians). While leaving they also guided us to the metro stations from which we were supposed to take our connections to our hotels. Overall, we loved the food here and would come back here when and if we come down to Madrid. Definitely recommended!!!

title_review: Avoid like the plague unless being poisoned is your thing!
review_preview: I visited this restaurant with five others for my friend´s birthday just over three weeks ago. Before going, we had checked the restaurant´s website, menu and various reviews from trusted websites; all in all we decided to give it a go. The birthday girl unfortunately...
review_full: I visited this restaurant with five others for my friend´s birthday just over three weeks ago. Before going, we had checked the restaurant´s website, menu and various reviews from trusted websites; all in all we decided to give it a go.  The birthday girl unfortunately has strong allergies towards anything containing nuts, fish and coconut milk so before going we double checked the menu for these traces (none were found).  Upon arriving, we were seated by the manageress who was pleasant enough (this was all about to change).. After being seated, we started to skim through the menu to which there were no allergy advisories etc. so we asked the manageress, who adamantly told us that only ONE curry had coconut milk in it....as someone who loves their curry, I know full well that a main ingredient is COCONUT MILK so how was this possible? Anyway, we asked her a few more times just to be sure and stated that my friend would become extremely ill if she ate any of these ingredients.. The food came, my friend was feeling a little apprehensive so she only tried a small amount of the food to see if she got a reaction, well 10 minutes later, can you guess what happened?...she was in the toilet throwing her guts up and bleeding internally from the throat!  When telling the manageress this, she was extremely rude and ignorant! I was utterly disgusted by her attitude. She sat there and denied that the food she had served us had nuts or coconut milk in them, her response "you can take the food to a laboratory for tasting if you do not believe" - are you kidding me?  My friend was ill that whole night and the rest of the day after.  The food was ok, nothing special. The curries were luminous, bright colours that looked like they had been poured straight out of a jar and heated up with some meat!  Overall, I would never come back here. Rude and negligent staff and rubbish food.

title_review: Great Food, Great Service, Great Price
review_preview: We went on a Saturday for brunch, and were not at all dissapointed. I recommend making a reservation, as we were lucky to get a tall table before the place filled up.  In Madrid, this is probably one of the best brunches for your money....
review_full: We went on a Saturday for brunch, and were not at all dissapointed. I recommend making a reservation, as we were lucky to get a tall table before the place filled up. In Madrid, this is probably one of the best brunches for your money. For 25 euros, we each had drinks (mimosas and a bloody mary), coffee, plus two dishes, which in the end was too much food for the two of us. I would especially recommend the salmon, bacon, and avacado eggs benedict which was delicious. Service was quick and friendly, and it is a great, cozy, neighborhood spot. If you are looking for a breezy terrace or a nice view, it's not your place. But, if you are looking for good American-style brunch serviced with a smile, then you should check it out! We will definitely be back, and we'll bring more people.

review_preview: As a predominantly vegetarian family we frequently find ourselves picking our way around menus in restaurants so it’s exciting to be able to order anything. Spoilt for choice, Artemisia sol has a wide range of dishes and cuisines on offer. We all had a starter...
review_full: As a predominantly vegetarian family we frequently find ourselves picking our way around menus in restaurants so it’s exciting to be able to order anything. Spoilt for choice, Artemisia sol has a wide range of dishes and cuisines on offer. We all had a starter and main each so tried quite a range. The gazpacho was delicious, the vichyssoise very heavy on cream and the crepes the size of a main course, but tasty. As for mains, my son had a rice dish containing mushrooms and seaweed and it was, he said, the best rice dish he’s ever had. My veggie paella was meh, the stir fried wok dish with noodles, veggies and tofu, stodgy and seemed dumped on the plate. The pasta with pesto was tasty but it’s hard to mess that up and the veggie bolognese poor. There was pasta (nicely cooked) with almost no soya bolognese...it should have been the other way round in terms of proportions. The waitress and service was absolutely delightful. I’d recommend a meal here if you’re wanting veggie food but beware the portion sizes and lack of finesse.

review_full: Restaurante Solidere - if you need authentic lebanese with a good ambiance & excellent food, this is the place to go. The food was delicious . We ordered Humus, Fatush, Falafal, Shish Tauk & Lamb Meshawai followed by a traditional lebanese dessert ome ali. Their falafal was the best we have had ever.  Complimentary green tea was served after the dinner.  The restaurant has an outdoor shisha sitting place as well.  Ambiance is very good & the service was fast. The dishes are on a slightly higher price side. We were a group of 5 and our bill was almost 70euros.  It is located almost 15 mins (by car) from downtown in a quiet & chic neighbourhood away from the packed tourist spots.  Overall highly recommended.

title_review: Lovely for vegan and vegetarian food
review_preview: We had some delicious food at this smallish but cosy place in the centre of Madrid.  There was only one person looking after all the diners but he raced around and did an amazing job - friendly and efficient.  All vegan dishes are marked on...
review_full: We had some delicious food at this smallish but cosy place in the centre of Madrid. There was only one person looking after all the diners but he raced around and did an amazing job - friendly and efficient. All vegan dishes are marked on the menu - very useful. We started with a large Antillano salad to share - a delicious mixture of fruits and salad items in a guacamole sauce. We followed with a Vegetarian Wok and a Courgette Queen of Africa (stuffed courgettes) - both interesting and tasty. We ended with chocolate, and carrot and pumpkin tarts - both brilliant. We had an organic bottle of red Rioja too. A really nice meal, good service and a fun atmosphere. Definitely recommend a visit - one of the best vegan/veggie places we went to.

Pablo, the owner born in Montevideo, welcomes you and goes to every table talking to people, speaking about food in his typical platino accent.

title_review: A work of art in food
review_preview: On a midsummer evening the nicely appointed restaurant was comfortably busy but not full  and service was charming and attentive but the real star was the food. We picked the menu at 65Euro and that was the best and only decision we had to make....
review_full: On a midsummer evening the nicely appointed restaurant was comfortably busy but not full and service was charming and attentive but the real star was the food. We picked the menu at 65Euro and that was the best and only decision we had to make. What followed was a parade of carefully curated dishes and we eventually lost count but think there were ten courses. We had razor clams,mussels, lobster, beef marrow and beef cheeks, lamb bow,scallops, fish, and these are just the ones I can remember. Each dish was art and food and had secret surprise flavours and textures that were delightful. Servings were more generous than usual tasting menus. Dessert at the end combined fruit and chocolate in a range of tastes. Chef is in the dining room for much of the evening and I suspect he takes personal pride in seeing how much we enjoyed the experience. This is a memorable meal and a highlight of the visit in Madrid.

title_review: DEEPLY FLAVORFUL, CREATIVE, ATTRACTIVE SPANISH-CHINESE RESTAURANT
review_preview: I've been to Soy Kitchen three times to date (the first time in June 2017 and more recently, alone and with a friend in June 2018). Each time I picked the 5-course 50 euro menú degustación (tasting menu), with the wine pairings (about 20 euros)....
review_full: I've been to Soy Kitchen three times to date (the first time in June 2017 and more recently, alone and with a friend in June 2018). Each time I picked the 5-course 50 euro menú degustación (tasting menu), with the wine pairings (about 20 euros). There was also a 65-euro 7-course tasting menu (which was supposed to show off the chef at his most unfettered) and, I believe, an a la carte option: I found the 5-course menú degustación quite varied and spectacular each time. On each of the three occasions the chef never repeated himself, although I began to notice famliar themes and combinations. So the dining experience was always at once reassuring and surprising. I know they also offer a 35-euro 3-course mid-day menú ejecutivo (executive three-course prix-fixe menu), in which they promise to give customers a taste of the chef´s range in 45 minutes (for those on a clock).  The chef, Yong Ping (who goes by Julio in Spain), is phenomenal: this, apparently, is his third restaurant and his most personal to date. He spent, I take it, 4 years in a Spanish restaurant in Pamplona, and this shows in his peculiarly successful wedding of culinary traditions. So-called fusion gastronomy can often degenerate into a pastiche or parody, a poorly improvised mish-mash of dishes from different traditions or else a rehash of all-too familiar themes. Yong Ping, in contrast, truly integrates ingredients, seasonings, and techniques from Spanish, Chinese, Andean, and even Thai or Japanese. He'll not just throw together ingredients or seasonings: he'll take a Spanish product, give it a Chinese treatment, and add an Andean, Thair or Japanese twist. And vice versa. Never just for its own sake or to show off but to bring out the strengths of whatever is in season together with the richest integration of flavors and textures: I say "richest" advisedly because this is not minimalist cooking. I don't mean it's heavy or over-abundant (it''s not): I mean rather that he aims for and achieves a rare complexity in flavor and texture that invariably works on the palate and deeply satisfies. He has a kind of perfect culinary pitch that way and I have found it fascinating to explore his latest creations whenever I am lucky enough to be in that great, impossible to overpraise city. Despite the aesthetic ambition, Yong Ping and his staff are the soul of warmth and earthiness: he likes to recommend he use our hands (e.g., for shellfish) because he says everything tastes better that way. I should add that in most recent visits (June 2018) the sumiller was a lively, knowledgeable, twinkle in his eye Madrilene man whose name is Raúl; he not only has a command of many of the most interesting unusual finds in the extraordinarily diversified and constantly innovating world of Spanish wine, he is extremely sensitive and responsive to customers (so the first night, when I said I didn't want so many wine pairings, he brought out 4 instead). The restaurant is well-lit, with a kind of contemporary, eclectic, laid-back chic decor, and a wait-staff that is attentive but never intrusive. A gem in a city chock-full of them.

Being a fan of Peruvian cuisine (I had the opportunity of tasting it in Lima some years ago, as well as in many other restaurants in Madrid, Paris, London, Vienna and Amsterdam), I have a pretty good idea each traditional dishes' flavors and ingredients. Inti de Oro is definitely a very good choice in Madrid if you like Peruvian cuisines. The amounts are generous and flavors authentic! You will not be disappointed. There are dishes for all palates.

title_review: Lovely staff and a great gin selection!
review_preview: My partner and I visited this bar for a drink and some late night tapas when we arrived in madrid. I had read the reviews on trip advisor and noticed it was near our hotel on the Gran Via. Whilst the surrounding neighbourhood is a...
review_full: My partner and I visited this bar for a drink and some late night tapas when we arrived in madrid. I had read the reviews on trip advisor and noticed it was near our hotel on the Gran Via. Whilst the surrounding neighbourhood is a bit tired, the bar well made up for it! The service was impeccable - staff were welcoming, friendly and gave lots of helpful recommendations. The bar has an excellent gin selection, serves up good tapas (i'd go for the patatas con jamon y huevo!) and includes complementary chocolate cake! One slight moan is that the toilets were not the cleanest but do not let this put you off - visiting this bar is a great experience!

I hope they keep it up like this!!! Grand!!!!

review_preview: My wife is from Peru. I've dined at many Peruvian restaurants in Peru and abroad. Don't be fooled by a bad review of this restaurant which must have been made by a competitor. Inti de Oro, is the real deal. The food was as good,...

Inti de Oro, is the real deal. The food was as good, if not far exceeding that of of what I've had in Peru.  I had the menu which included: a pisco sour, a tasting portion of a potato casserole, Cusquena beer, a plate inuding a variety of appetizers, lomo saltaldo entree, desert of suspiro de limena, and an after drink of algorrobina - all for only 24 euros! Fantastic!

I would definitely recommend and I will definitely go back!!

review_preview: When the restaurant where we wanted to have lunch was closed, my husband and I stumbled across La Pasa. From the minute we stepped inside this small bar, the bartender/server made us feel welcome. He chatted with us for several minutes, answered our many questions...
review_full: When the restaurant where we wanted to have lunch was closed, my husband and I stumbled across La Pasa. From the minute we stepped inside this small bar, the bartender/server made us feel welcome. He chatted with us for several minutes, answered our many questions with clear explanations, and helped us to find some truly delicious, fairly priced entrees. If you eat meat, I'd highly recommend the Secreto Iberico plate, which is a locally raised pork served with pan fried potatoes in a porcini mushroom sauce -- scrumptious! Also, the pimientos de Padrón were fresh and perfectly grilled (they reminded me of tiny mild poblanos). I also enjoyed the cappuccino. The only minor downside was that apparently there are no tables, just tall stools at the bar.

title_review: It's all about gin and tonic (and it's great)!
review_preview: I'm no fan of gin, and certainly not mixed with tonic. It's probably the last thing I would order from a bar. But the good reviews and the dedication to the popular and abused drink made me curious. And it payed off, twice. This is...
review_full: I'm no fan of gin, and certainly not mixed with tonic. It's probably the last thing I would order from a bar. But the good reviews and the dedication to the popular and abused drink made me curious. And it payed off, twice. This is a serious bar, although it's simple in all ways. This is no high-end cocktail bar (which I adore and often go to), but the service is what you could expect from the greatest. The varieties of gin are amazing, but it not stopping there. The preparation of the drinks are made especially based on the chosen gin: lemon or lime, added spices and brand of tonic! On my two visits me and my friends tried four different gins, and they were comepletely different drinks!  Forget Tangueray and Bombay Sapphire, and go here to get the most different GT you ever had: just let the bartenders do their job!

review_full: We tried La Pasa after finding it on trip advisor.  We had only one night in Madrid so were looking for somewhere local. When we arrived at 8:30pm the bar was packed! We made our way through the crowd and found the seated restaurant out the back.  The friendly bar tender was very accommodating and looked after us very well even with a busy bar.  We had hamburgers which were fantastic. I really like the chilly side sauce with corn chips that came with the big burgers. My father had the five mini burgers and loved them! We had a few drinks with dinner and then had some delicious desserts.  We also met the friendly owner who made us laugh and gave us a special drink after dinner.  Fantastic night out. 6 out of 5

review_preview: We hung around outside the bar trying to decide where to go. A dark man came out smiling and launched into a stream of Spanish we could not keep up with. We looked at each other. He asked us where we were from, in English....
review_full: We hung around outside the bar trying to decide where to go. A dark man came out smiling and launched into a stream of Spanish we could not keep up with. We looked at each other. He asked us where we were from, in English. We told him. "Ah Australia. I live upstairs with two people, two girls. One, she is Australian." We talked some more. When he spoke, he looked only at Susannah. I couldn't get sore; she was beautiful after all. I didn't blame him.  Susannah asked if they did vegetarian food and he said yes and he invited us in. We went in.  There was just one couple at the bar because it was siesta and a Monday and everyone probably thought we were crazy or ignorant for trying to eat at a time like that. But we did eat, and drink - a lot, for very little money. It was good.

review_preview: This is by far my favorite bar in Madrid. I remember the first time I visited; My friends and I had just gotten to Madrid, and were waiting to move into our hotel. Within minutes, we had sent down our suitcases, and the Bartender and...
review_full: This is by far my favorite bar in Madrid. I remember the first time I visited; My friends and I had just gotten to Madrid, and were waiting to move into our hotel. Within minutes, we had sent down our suitcases, and the Bartender and Owner handed us some delicious Gin and Tonics made with Spanish Gin, and asked us about where we were from, where we were staying, what we wanted to see while we were here, etc.. He was so nice to us, and he really helped us feel welcome in Madrid, and even tried to give us some Spanish lessons. We spent hours there, talking, and enjoying his company. The drinks are hand crafted, and are artful in ingredients and taste. They have about every kind of Gin you could possibly imagine, each one better than the last. The food is absolutely to die-for, and is perfect in flavor, quality, and value. I still have dreams about the Caramelized Onion Tortilla.... I cannot recommend this bar enough. Even if you are not a Gin kind of person, it is still worth a visit. Every-time I have stopped in, the entire place is packed full of happy people enjoying each-other's company. The service is possibly the best I have seen in Europe, definitely in Spain, and you will be treated like family. I can guarantee you will want to go back every chance you get.

review_full: I went at 2030 on a Friday night (early for Madrid!) with a Spanish and Mexican couple I know. I was a little nervous to begin with as the restaurant initially appeared closed at 2030. The were not and the restaurant rapidly filled up. The staff were very informative and efficient. The food was explained to us at every stage and presented really nicely. My favourite was a pulled chicken dish with new potatoes in a rich creamy sauce. A guitarist sang at each table and explained the origins of the songs for us as he sang. All in all a lovely night out and albeit a little expensive it was well worth it in my opinion!

review_full: We stumbled across this restaurant and not having sampled Peruvian food before,we thought we would give it a try. Started with a Peruvian cocktail, very nice. Before our starter arrived we were given a pre starter of a small bread crumbed ball with meat inside, in a yellow sauce.....delicious! The warm bread we were given had a tasty chilling sauce with it, not too strong. Our starter was scallops in a cheese sauce and breadcrumbs, loved it. My main course was wild sea bass in an amazing sauce. There were also prawns and pieces of squid, along with rice. Amazing! We also had a dessert and a glass of wine each. Price for our most delicious meal and drinks was 72 euros. Staff were very friendly and attentive. We enjoyed it so much that we booked a table for our last night in Madrid. That time we chose the tasting menu, which was yet another wonderful experience.

title_review: Luscious!  Pisco sours and papas rellenas!
review_preview: We had lunch here with a rather large group of friends some of whom had never had Peruvian food before.  A friend of ours who is an historian who specializes in Andean studies had recommended it as the best Peruvian food in Madrid and my...
review_full: We had lunch here with a rather large group of friends some of whom had never had Peruvian food before. A friend of ours who is an historian who specializes in Andean studies had recommended it as the best Peruvian food in Madrid and my husband who is from Ecuador was dying to go. It completely lived up to expectations. Because we were with a group, we tried several things on the menu and enjoyed them all! The papas rellenas (mashed potato stuffed with meat, olives, raisins and egg then fried) were fabulous as were the tamales and the anticuchos (skewers of marinated grilled steak). For entrees we had the tacu tacu (a rice and beans with seafood), the chichirones de chancho (fried pieces of pork) the gallina, (chicken in sauce) and the pollo norteño (another chicken) and the gallo en aji (capon in hot sauce). Almost all of it was excellent (although the one fault was that the chichirones were a little fattier than I'd like).  They also make excellent pisco sours, terrific alfajores (cookies with dulce de leche) and tremendously delicious suspiroes (dulce de leche topped with merengue).  Lunch for 7 adults with apps, entres, dessert, coffees, and drinks, tax and tip came to 176€ ($246) or roughly $35/person.

title_review: Authentic Peruvian pleasures on ‘Love of God’ Street
review_preview: There are two Intis de Oro and they’re not far from each other. We went for Sunday lunch to the one hidden away in Calle Amor de Dios (Metro: Antón Martín). The choice is both extensive and exotic: Tacu-tacu, Pollo Chi Jau Kay, arroz chaufa,...
review_full: There are two Intis de Oro and they’re not far from each other. We went for Sunday lunch to the one hidden away in Calle Amor de Dios (Metro: Antón Martín). The choice is both extensive and exotic: Tacu-tacu, Pollo Chi Jau Kay, arroz chaufa, sudado de corvine…all with their descriptions and sounding really interesting. In the end we opted for a great value 3 course set lunch, and very good it was too. We started with an aperitif of Pisco Sour and bread with ají amarrillo (a cream of ´slightly’ hot yellow chilli peppers!). The first course consisted of a mix of Peruvian starters: ceviche, papita rellena, causa limeña and fried yucca. There was a choice of 7 main courses, but we both played safe had ají de gallina (chicken) to which we added some of the yellow chilli sauce to give it a bit more bite….Everything was accompanied by a jug of sangria and followed by an original dessert. Total for two: 48 euro.  We’ll certainly be back as there are so many other Peruvian specialities to try and next time we’ll be more adventurous. The service was friendly and efficient. There were also lots of South Americans having lunch here which is always a good sign.

title_review: Great start, but with a few hiccups
review_preview: With the variety of restaurants found on the same street as Inti, you can imagine it is very competitive in terms of food and prices.I gave this place a try as there is a large Peruvian community in Spain, so I figured you will...
review_full: With the variety of restaurants found on the same street as Inti, you can imagine it is very competitive in terms of food and prices. I gave this place a try as there is a large Peruvian community in Spain, so I figured you will get good authentic food. As soon as you sit down, you get a Papá Huancaina, a tiny portion of a potato with a creamy spicy cheese sauce. Great start! Moving on to a drink and appetizer, you can't go wrong with a pisco sour and the ceviche. The pisco was generous, prepared on the spot with proper egg whites. The ceviche mixto has Mediterranean sea bass, prawns and octopus presented beautifully with crunchy corn in a perfectly balanced lime juice. At €15, it's not the cheapest option but it the portion is very generous. You could have this as a main easily or share it between two people. I was excited for the main course. I ordered the Aji de Gallina which is a chicken stew in a nutty, spicy creamy sauce served with white rice. The dish is simple but the presentation was poor, so different to the appetizer! I'm not sure what happened but as you can see in the picture, it looked like they slapped the food on the dish and kicked it out of the kitchen. Flavour wise, it was OK. The sauce is thick, bit on the heavy side with no real kick to it. I ended the night with a decadent "tres leches" cake which was a relief. Well presented, creamy and flavourful. The whipped cream was light and not overly sweet since the cake itself is already pretty sweet.  All in all, good food with some letdowns, and to leave a sour taste at the end of the night, they didn't take Amex which is ridiculous considering they cater mainly to tourists! Total bill came out to €42

review_preview: El Inti de Oro claims to be the first Peruvian restaurant in Spain, with a 25-year track record. It certainly has been one of our best experiences with Peruvian food in our travels. In so many cases, Peruvian is juxtaposed with other cuisines, like Japanese,...
review_full: El Inti de Oro claims to be the first Peruvian restaurant in Spain, with a 25-year track record. It certainly has been one of our best experiences with Peruvian food in our travels. In so many cases, Peruvian is juxtaposed with other cuisines, like Japanese, to create hybrid dishes, but this is the real thing - potatoes (of course), ceviche, satisfying meat dishes, cilantro sauce, yellow chilies (mild for the most part). It's small, so make a reservation - although we were able to snag a table at 8 PM on a Saturday without one.

Best part of this place as the sauces. Huankaina sauce was spot on! Lomo salteado perfectly cooked. BTW, Don't use "the fork" app to book rather call direct. If you're looking gor authentic Peruvian cuisine, you can't go wrong here!

title_review: Like South American barbecue?  Mano de Pablo is your place
review_preview: I have been to this place may times, and it never lets me down. A busy, noisy restaurant, where you enjoy the best meat and a complete ' Argentinean ' Asado ( sorry, it is Uruguayan, but he neighbor is more known internationally ). Try...
review_full: I have been to this place may times, and it never lets me down. A busy, noisy restaurant, where you enjoy the best meat and a complete ' Argentinean ' Asado ( sorry, it is Uruguayan, but he neighbor is more known internationally ). Try the melted cheese, provoleta, the sausages chorizo and morcilla ( blood sausage), the sweetbread - mollejas, the meats: the best one can find - try the 'tira de Asado', Uruguayan style ribs - the meat on the bone is always the best. For desert, pancake with dulce de leche is a must. Prices reasonable, and outside they will take care of your car which is important in this busy residential - office area of Madrid a little outside of the town ( Las Tablas)

review_preview: As the other reviews said, food is great. Empinada appetizer was outstanding, my wife's duck was spectacular, my steak was good. OK.. This restaurant is tiny. 10' wide, only half dozen tables. That's not a bad thing. Adds to the experience When you get to...
review_full: As the other reviews said, food is great. Empinada appetizer was outstanding, my wife's duck was spectacular, my steak was good.  OK.. This restaurant is tiny. 10' wide, only half dozen tables. That's not a bad thing. Adds to the experience  When you get to the door, it's easy to think there is another entry, as people are eating right there and no greeting station. PUSH the door (my daughter had to figure it out for us. We waived in the next family that was equally confused)  No food for kids. Half the tables included kids. My daughter is a fussy six year old. My suggestion is to have something available (even off menu like chicken and rice.. Or have some gourmet mac n cheese ).  The bread is 2/pp extra. Advice to the restaurant... Add 2 to every entree and make the bread free  Most entrees were 17. I tried to order the 29 tasting menu. Btw.. 1 hour after open on a Friday night. The waitress said they didn't have it. Really disappointed, as we were looking for an experience. No explanation why. Suggest taking it off the menu (it's just a printed one sided paper)  To sum it up, less than a five star experience... But the food was so good, I didn't want to bring down their score  Shoot me a message if you have any questions. If this was helpful, click on the thumbs up  Les and Leidy

review_preview: This is by far amongst my top favorite restaurants not only in Spain but in the world and I do not say that lightly as I have been all over the world. When we arrived, I saw this place was empty and quickly had second...
review_full: This is by far amongst my top favorite restaurants not only in Spain but in the world and I do not say that lightly as I have been all over the world.  When we arrived, I saw this place was empty and quickly had second thoughts but most of the comments on trip advisor experienced the same first impression but they urge to stay and eat. I took their advice. I have one word to describe the chef: genius.  The food is absolutely incredible. The duck was ridiculously delicious but so is pretty much everything on the menu. It is impossible to pick a favorite dish. Usually, most chefs hide behind the quality of their products yet they lack creativity and a deeper understanding of food. This chef is not one of those chefs. Not only creative but the balance you taste in his foods makes for a very satisfying experience. It's been a long time since I've had a satisfying experience in a restaurant where my taste buds aren't overwhelmed by combinations. This chef is a genius.  Let me put it in football terms: he isn't at Messi's level yet but he's definitely Dybala. He's on his way to something big.  This place is a MUST GO.

review_preview: We sampled the set 11.25 eur menu which was fantastic.  It is very popular with locals (only open from 13.30 to 15.00 for lunch and was completely full by 14.oo on a Thurs plus evenings most nights). and we were the only tourists that day....
review_full: We sampled the set 11.25 eur menu which was fantastic. It is very popular with locals (only open from 13.30 to 15.00 for lunch and was completely full by 14.oo on a Thurs plus evenings most nights). and we were the only tourists that day. There was a 3 course set menu with many choices as well as the usual a la carte. We had for example a bowl of creamy vege soup and a plate of wonderful hors d'horeves which included houmus, puree carrot and beetroot with grated carrot and sprouted aduki beans. With warm rustic bread this was welcome change from the usual lack of fresh veg or salad in the meals we experienced in Madrid. Main course was a delicious spinach cannelonni, vege burger or a plate of mixed dishes - ratatouille and couscous. this was followed by a huge choice of sweets such as fresh melon or mango tart or yoghurt. We did not have room for coffee after that! I noticed the chef had recently added 2 organic chicken recipes to the menu, so something for meat eaters too. review_full: I've been several times to La Mano de Pablo in Las Tablas. It is always crowded, and as such, there must be a reason. This is an Urugayan restaurant and so meat is a must. However, both service and food is not completely great. There are some items which are quite good, some other have less quality. For instance, pizza is, in my opinion, too thick and lacks "something" on top. Meat has been irregularly prepared, sometimes very good, sometimes below par. One of the things I do not like is that sometimes the meat is not cook as per order. Service is sometimes also an issue, always gentle, but being such a large restaurant they forget about some things from time to time. In essence, it is a good restaurant, but I think they should be more careful with the food (which is not bad at all, but could be better) and add one or two more waiters.

title_review: Friends visit - have a good time
review_preview: Once thing I've learned is to no seek for the food type and quality I get at home when I am travelling. I was invited to this Uruguayan owned restaurant and had a nice dinner with UY's style barbecue and pizza. Pizza was really good...
review_full: Once thing I've learned is to no seek for the food type and quality I get at home when I am travelling. I was invited to this Uruguayan owned restaurant and had a nice dinner with UY's style barbecue and pizza. Pizza was really good and very similar to the one we get at home and it was well stuffed and had fresh ingredients. Pablo, the owner, shared with us that his 2nd restaurant was closed to ensure he was able to serve and handle the quality he aims, with multiple places and different direction style he was not being able to do so. The food is similar to the one you can get in UY, some interesting facts about our visit. - FAINÁ (which is flatbread or crust made with chickpea flour) was very good, large serving and cheaper than in Uruguay!!! EUR 3.70 while in UY is about UYU70 pesos for half size portion. - BBQ for two, it was EUR 52, it included MORCILLA (black pudding) and chorizo (sausage), MORCILLA like made in UY is impossible to get anywhere else, we have sweet and salty one, the ones I’ve tried around always have a "cumin" taste. This was significantly more expensive than in UY, it’s understandable as the meat quality and price is higher here. The restaurant includes white table setting and it has an upscale look and feel, it's not like the ones you can get this kind of food in UY, but if you're in Spain and you're interested to see our pizza and FAINÁ style, definitely you have to visit this place. I have not done BBQ anywhere else in Spain, so can't compare and tell if there are any better places for this or not, it was similar to ours, but not just like ours. Also, they serve Picaña, which is usually referred to as the rump cover or rump cap in the US. Also, as main difference the fat is not removed from the cut until the steak has been cooked or just served with it, some people like to eat this some others like me not, i would even prefer to get it cooked without fat, but in most "parrillas" this is not possible as they have some cuts that take long already pre-cooked or slightly grilled. For sweets we had "dulce de leche panqueue" which was AWESOME and "CHAJÁ” which is a typical uruguayan sweet made with meringue, dulce de leche , whipped cream in a base of biscuits. Also you can find with strawberry or peach instead of dulce de leche (caramel sauce) Nice dinner for 4, 6 beers, 2 cockes, bread, bbq for 2, Sweetbread appetizer, pizza for two, 1 caramel rolled panqueue and 1 cajá was EUR 104 for a dinner of 4. EUR 26 pp.

review_full: What can I say, one of the best restaurants I've ever been to! From the start, you are greeted warmly inside a intimate Bistro and then walked through the menu by a charming chef who is clearly passionate about what he does. And boy does it show in the food, the empanadas, steak & fish are all highlights, the passion fruit meringue to finish was maybe even the best dish we had. We booked online and saved 30% but would've happily paid full price, or more, it really was that good! The photos don't do it justice, the steak was cooked to perfection and served with a lovely selection of vegetables that didn't overpower it. The fish was lovely and unusual, it was fish of the day so likely to change but will be up to the great standard of the bistro without a doubt. We're here for 7 days and already considering coming back on our last night to try the rest of the menu!

If you like good food, a nice and cosy atmosphere, then I strongly recommend it!

review_preview: Followed recent advice on trip advisor and booked with less than an hour's notice and got 40% discount coz I reserved a table for one through the fork.But that didn't matter. Would have paid full price after eating anyway.I was the only one...
review_full: Followed recent advice on trip advisor and booked with less than an hour's notice and got 40% discount coz I reserved a table for one through the fork. But that didn't matter. Would have paid full price after eating anyway. I was the only one in the restaurant at 830 but I knew it would get busier as it had only just opened. Had the choice of sitting and offered to choose a wine when I couldn't decide. Chef came out to explain the menu as it was in Spanish and I went for the pate special starter and the Argentinian cut of meat for main. Pate was delicious. Not sure what I liked most. Homemade chutney, nut crust, pate or the dusting of cocoa powder. The main came out smelling amazing. Cooked as per the chef's preference which was almost rare but perfect. The blackened crust of pepper and salt made the meal enhanced by the baby onions and slice of turnip, which I don't normally like. I thought I ordered a chocolate and ginger trifle but to my utter joy I was served three balls of ginger ice cream. All coated in cocoa powder with honeycomb and nut sprinkles which resulted in one of the best desserts I've ever eaten. Ribeiro wine was bloody delicious too.

title_review: Worth a detour for the guacamole
review_preview: We miss Mexican cuisine more than any other when we travel, so we were happy to discover Oyamel midway between the Sorolla museum and our hotel near the Prado--a very pleasant walk.The restaurant's interior is much smaller than we had anticipated, but quite comfortable,...
review_full: We miss Mexican cuisine more than any other when we travel, so we were happy to discover Oyamel midway between the Sorolla museum and our hotel near the Prado--a very pleasant walk. The restaurant's interior is much smaller than we had anticipated, but quite comfortable, especially along the wall opposite the bathrooms. Reservations are recommended. There is also outdoor seating opposite the entrance, though it wasn't immediately obvious to us that it was part of Oyamel. The guacamole was indeed spectacular...possibly the best we have ever had. The dish was quite small however, and we think would better serve as an appetizer for one person than two. Likewise, the mojitos were excellent, but a bit skimpy once the mint and ice were accounted for. One entrees, large grilled shrimp in the shell, and marinated beef tacos were good but not outstanding. The friendly service brought this review from three stars to four, but adjust your expectations accordingly.

It’s always nice to go in t9 a restaurant abroad and be able to take pot luck and know you can eat what you order- that said, this didn’t happen as they have a English menu anyway. We had the vegetable croquettes which were very nice and then for the main, we had one of their tasting plates- what a good idea, more places should do this and Artemisa did 4. We went for the number 3 plate which was mousakka, quinoa cous cous with honey, cinnamon and caramelised grilled vegetables with goat cheese, mushrooms crêpes and tofu sticks with Teriyaki sauce. It was all very tasty, the tofu was very well cocked which not everyone can do, the mousakka was lovely but the star of the show, and I was contemplating not getting the number 3 plate, was the cous cous, which I am generally not a fan of. This was delicious. We also had a very nice and reasonably priced bottle of house red wine.

We both picked "el menu del dia" which included a starter, a main, a drink + a desert or coffee. I think that the price was around 13€ per person. Our bill came slightly higher as we ordered delicious fresh fruit juices not included in the set menu. The service was very quick, staff very friendly. I loved my "plato combinado" made of portions of several dishes : stuffed pepper, rice with soya sausages, aubergine with yogurt sauce. Very tasty food / several vegan options available. Good location as near Plaza Santa Ana.

title_review: Take these rave reviews with a pinch of salt
review_preview: Tripadvisor advertises itself as "reviews you can trust" - which might possibly be true with hotels but when it comes to restaurants I am increasingly being frustrated by unjustifiable rave reviews from (whom I can only assume to be) students and budget back-packers with a...
review_full: Tripadvisor advertises itself as "reviews you can trust" - which might possibly be true with hotels but when it comes to restaurants I am increasingly being frustrated by unjustifiable rave reviews from (whom I can only assume to be) students and budget back-packers with a very different ordering of priorities.  Anyone reading these reviews is given the impression that this is an eat-in pizzeria with basic but comfortable tables and chairs and hopefully a wine list of sorts.  The 4 rage reviews (plus one dissenter) of Pizzeria El Trebol is symptomatic of this problem. The over-enthusiastic descriptions "best pizza in Spain", "best pizza I have ever eaten" and even "best pizza ever, including New York" should all be taken with a large pinch of salt. Why? Because not one of these rave reviewers bothers to mention the crucial fact that this is not a sit-in restaurant at all - it is a very tiny "hole-in-the-wall" takeaway with just one tiny table and a very narrow shelf (20cm deep if that) along the wall (cannot be more than 2m) with a couple of stools.  After tramping miles looking for this place I quickly retreated in great disappointment as soon as I saw what it really was, so I cannot verify whether or not this is a great pizza but if these are the opinions of the ultra-budget conscious then I would be very dubious.

title_review: Friendly, cosy, great atmosphere with delicious food and drink
review_preview: This place does the best pizza in Madrid and is probably the best pizza I've ever tasted. Pizzeria El Trebol reminds me of a small Parisian bar/restaurant with it's decor, style and buzzing atmosphere. There's only 2 men who are the owners and workers of...
review_full: This place does the best pizza in Madrid and is probably the best pizza I've ever tasted. Pizzeria El Trebol reminds me of a small Parisian bar/restaurant with it's decor, style and buzzing atmosphere. There's only 2 men who are the owners and workers of the pizzeria. They were very friendly and helpful. They told me they opened the pizzeria 17 years ago and they're always busy at night. I went there on my birthday and they gave us free drinks. I liked the pizza best and the small toilet the least. The pizzeria opens at 8.30pm and it has beer, spirits, pastries, radio music plus your pizza is made fresh in front of you. I went there 3 times in 1 week....I absolutely love the food, drink and service of Pizzeria El Trebol.

title_review: Terrific vegetarian restaurant in the center of Madrid
review_preview: This is the place to go for a respite from meat in Madrid - and very good. The extensive menu 2 of us split the 'Plato combinado degustación' for lunch. It was a tour de force of quiche, tarta, olive tapenade, stuffed mushroom.... What a...
review_full: This is the place to go for a respite from meat in Madrid - and very good. The extensive menu  2 of us split the 'Plato combinado degustación' for lunch. It was a tour de force of quiche, tarta, olive tapenade, stuffed mushroom.... What a selection of tasty and different foods - we could not finish it. Another person got the musaka which he loved and the last person got the spinach dish which she loved as well. She also ordered the curried vegetables and it was not as excellent as the others.  We got the Tarta Artemisa de chocolate dessert to split amongst us and it was excellent. They did not have the tiramisu. Ambience - very friendly but not a place to linger long. The food comes quickly and the waiters rushing up and down the aisles. They do not push you out - so they are not rushing you. A very busy place so either get there when it opens or make a reservation. Bathrooms good.

review_preview: As a vegan, walking through Madrid past all of the meat/pigs legs displayed in every window, you wonder if there are any decent places for plant-based foods in this city. And there are...quite a few in fact. And Artemisa is by far one of the...
review_full: As a vegan, walking through Madrid past all of the meat/pigs legs displayed in every window, you wonder if there are any decent places for plant-based foods in this city. And there are...quite a few in fact. And Artemisa is by far one of the best. After reading reviews this was the first place we stopped for food after arriving in Madrid and it did not dissapoint! We arrived during the lunch period so we both opted for the set lunch menu - a starter, a main,  desert and wine. All for around 12 euros each! Starters included salads, soups, bread etc... all fresh ingredients and unique tasting vegan/veggie dishes. Main course varied each day, and you would get a choice on that day of three or four things that were available. During our stay we visited several times for lunch, but my favorite dish had to be the Vegan lasagne, closely followed by the vegan paella. Deserts included fruit platters, vegan tarts, cheesecakes, chocolate deserts, a huge variety! Vegan custard cake is the one to go for though :) We were told we could have a glass of wine included with our meal, however our waitress just left a full bottle on the table for us to help ourselves. Which leads me on to my final point: excellent service! Although there was a language barrier and the staff were quite clearly rushed off their feet, the service was a delight. Other things to note - Free wifi,  available. There are no set dinner menus so three course meal will be considerably more if visiting in the evening (I highly recommend going for lunch). Closes around 4pm-ish and reopens around 9pm. There is another Artemisa restaurant a short walk away, both do exceptional food but I recommend this one for the ultimate vegan dining experience.

review_full: I was city centre looking for a place for dinner, and hoping to find some good heart-warming gluten free food. I was so happy to see that EVERYTHING on this restaurant's menu is gluten free (as well as vegetarian)!  They can also do anything on the menu to take away, which I opted for as I was tired from a long day of meetings and I liked the idea of having a lovely meal in the hotel room, watching some local tv.  The portion sizes are very big, so the waiter recommended to order just a main, and dessert if I felt like it. I opted for some grilled aubergine with cheese, which was so nice and definitely very filling!  I ordered a glass of wine while I waited for the food to be ready, and the waiter brought me some complimentary corn chips with homemade dip, which was wonderful and quite a big bowl!  The highlight, I must say, was the tiramisu. Having a wheat intolerance means I don't get to try desserts very often, and this tiramisu was, again, a very portion and amazing - I think it's one of the best I've tried (even from before I got my wheat intolerance!). And btw, if you do take away (as I did) you get a discount on the total bill! It was a yummy, filling, comforting and very affordable meal. I will definitely come back and I recommend Artemisa to anyone (not just to GF or vegetarians as the food and service was great).

title_review: Useful for Vegetarians staying in central Madrid
review_preview: It isn't always easy to be a vegetarian in Madrid, as there is quite a lot of 'lurking' lard in some recipes.  So it was with relief that we sat down at our table in Artemisa.  The ambiance was wholesome and simple and the waiter...
review_full: It isn't always easy to be a vegetarian in Madrid, as there is quite a lot of 'lurking' lard in some recipes. So it was with relief that we sat down at our table in Artemisa. The ambiance was wholesome and simple and the waiter was friendly and helpful - in fact he advised us not to order as much as we were going to, and he was right. The portions are large and excellent value. My partner and I ended up sharing three dishes: crepes filled with brie and mushrooms for a starter - big enough for a main course! - then a salad (which turned out to be sweet, so would have been better at the end of the meal) and finally a veggie paella. The restaurant also caters for the gluten-intolerant, which may have explained the less-than-perfect crepes. The paella was a bit salty and uninspired. The salad however was truly heavenly - a huge platter of a variety of fruits, perfectly ripe, with a delicious mango mousse in the middle. The wine was OK and very cheap. Overall, an enjoyable experience but don't expect haute cuisine!

review_preview: My wife and I came to Artemisa for lunch after visiting the Prado: we sought it ought based on a review in our guidebook as my wife is vegetarian and veggie-friendly provision in normal Spanish restaurants can be limited!We were lucky enough to arrive...
review_full: My wife and I came to Artemisa for lunch after visiting the Prado: we sought it ought based on a review in our guidebook as my wife is vegetarian and veggie-friendly provision in normal Spanish restaurants can be limited! We were lucky enough to arrive and be seated straight away at around 1.30 PM: there was a queue of people waiting for tables for most of the time we were there. We had the menu del dia at lunchtime, which we really enjoyed: we each started with soup, then had a sample platter with a range of different vegetarian dishes and finished off with cake and coffee. The menu was great value at c€12 each. Service was fine but a bit slow as the restaurant was very busy: there wasn't an English menu available, but the waiter could translate. I'd recommend this to any vegetarians visiting Madrid! For omnivores, it's worth a look for the menu of the day but probably not worth queueing for, especially as there's a wide range of restaurants on the Calle Venture de la Vega and the adjacent Calle del Prado.

The owner and his wife [?] could redo the role of the soup nazi in Seinfeld --- they're both rather intimidating. BUT people love this place, especially the locals. There is a three course lunch special with various options for each course. The salad we had was great but unfortunately the entree was not as great as we had hoped for. There are not a lot of vegetarian options that we were aware of, but this restaurant for us was a disappointment.

review_full: Madrid is not the best place for vegetarians who largely abstain from grains and dairy. This restaurant was recommended as "the" place to go. Oh dear. The menus in the tapas places vary little and the one here is quite distinctive, so there's no wonder why it might be popular. (The wait can be really long). The salad was quite delicious and fresh tasting, but the entrees were not pleasing to us in either flavor or texture. We advise skipping it and devising a meal from the supermarket.

title_review: Couldn't get enough of this restaurant
review_preview: This restaurant was one of the best vegetarian places we went to through our 10 day Spain trip. During 1.5 days in Madrid, we went to this place 3 times (most of the main meals). If we could, we would pack some of the meals...
review_full: This restaurant was one of the best vegetarian places we went to through our 10 day Spain trip. During 1.5 days in Madrid, we went to this place 3 times (most of the main meals). If we could, we would pack some of the meals for our trip back. We also met the chef Manuel, who was down to earth and friendly. He welcomed us and also guided on through the menu (we don't speak Spanish). The meals were unique and delicious (we have traveled quite a bit). The deserts were some of the best we have had. The coffee cake is what I would recommend along with the vitamin juice. The meal combinations were a great way to sample different meals. Glad we got a chance to experience this place.

review_full: OK, I am not prone to exaggeration and I have well over 100 reviews on TripAdvisor, of which this is the most negative by some considerable distance. The empanadas and the pizza bases are all bought in, nothing whatsoever is made fresh. When I arrived just before 2000hrs I was offered stale pizza slices from lunchtime service. I ordered a 'fresh' pizza, thoroughly expecting there to be some skilled chef out the back, instead I had an assembly job of pre-bought components topped off with an excessive quantity of dried poor quality oregano. It was truly awful. Avoid at all costs. If it were not for the TripAdvisor obscenity filter so could have reviewed this place in five words or less. Sometimes the TripAdvisor algorithm throws up some anomalous ratings. This place is anomalous and I nearly threw up. Do not eat here. Ever.

review_preview: We had a really good dinner here after being frustrated by the lack of vegetarian options on our trip to Spain.  Plus, were were pretty hungry when we got here.  The waiter was just this side of sassy, but he was prompt with the food...
review_full: We had a really good dinner here after being frustrated by the lack of vegetarian options on our trip to Spain. Plus, were were pretty hungry when we got here. The waiter was just this side of sassy, but he was prompt with the food and was very helpful with recommendations. The restaurant was near our hotel in the Gran Via so that was very convenient. Ask for an English menu if you have trouble with the Spanish. They have one and we found it very helpful. We ordered the veggie lasagna, pizza with brie and goat cheese, mousaka (eggplant based dish) and spinach cannelloni. They were all hearty and delicious. The meal included bread, which was very good, but we had to buy water since in Spain they don't bring free water to the table. We ate after 9 pm on a Thursday night and it wasn't crowded at all. They did not require reservations since there were just 4 of us. All in all, we would probably eat there again.

Overall though, the atmosphere was good, and the starters/drinks decent.

review_full: Had a reservation confirmed for Sunday July 1, 2018 at 14:00 for 11 people to celebrate my wife's birthday. Reservation confirmed by Cosme several days before. We went there around 13:30 and restaurant was closed though there is a note on their website that on Sundays they are only open from 13:30-16:30, there is also an advisory on their door of these same hours. We waited for them to open but they never did! There was no advisory anywhere that they were not going to open and phone calls to the restaurant went unanswered. Around 13:45 a group of 6 people came stating that they also had a confirmed reservation for 14:00, they also knocked at the door and called to no avail. At 14:15 we went across the street to Olivia Restaurante and were served well, the group of 6 also went with us. Can't understand why Cosme would confirm a reservation and then not honor it! Cosme also had our cel/mobile number and our e-mail but did nothing to contact us nor the group of 6 other people! We have been there 3 times in the past 2 years and were served well.

review_preview: We went to this restaurant after reading the reviews below too. We ordered a starter which was pretty nice served with tzatziki, which arrived pretty promptly. This was large enough for two people. This was nearly as good as the one we had in Athens,...
review_full: We went to this restaurant after reading the reviews below too. We ordered a starter which was pretty nice served with tzatziki, which arrived pretty promptly. This was large enough for two people. This was nearly as good as the one we had in Athens, a few days before. However, it could have been served with more salad! The main arrived and I was horrified at the sight of it. I stupidly thought it may taste better. How wrong we both were. We ordrered the Artemisa I, which consisted of 4/5 different things. Don't bother. The spinach was wilted with pinenuts and it was dressed in a milky vile cheesey type sauce. Absolutely vile!. The paella was bland, tasted curried and contained courgettes, cauliflower and it tasted wrong, needed to be binned too! The moussaka tasted the best from the lot, not difficult considered how awful the majority of it was. It was dry and bland and needed more sauce. The courgette balls tasted curried and weren't too unpleasant, they needed a sauce to go with them too. How could I nearly forget the bland and flavourless vegetable burger. No idea what it was made of, the taste was totally forgettable. Perhaps this restaurant caters for the the Spanish market, however, t it did nothing for me or my partner. We ordered coffee and cake, as we had an unpleasant after taste in our mouths, and worse this taste still lingered in the morning after. Avoid this restaurant like the plague, unless you enjoy being a glutton for awful food. Go to Lamucca de Prado or Indian Aroma next door. (Yummy food at both places). I have no idea how the reviews below gave them such high scores. I would refuse to eat, even if someone paid me.

We chose Artemisa because although we are meat/fish eaters we thought it would make for some interesting flavours. It was good although very quiet, possibly because it was a Monday night. She was quite right as we shared one starter and had a main selection course which was for sharing. That was plenty of food and we are not small portion people. The main selection was very good with several different items giving varying tastes. Nice bottle of red. Total cost around 50 Euros so very reasonable for city centre food.

title_review: Good food in a somewhat prosaic ambiance
review_preview: On our first evening in Madrid, we tried Artemisa Huertas Cortes in Calle de Ventura de la Vega. Vegetarian restaurants in Madrid are rather scanty, so being vegetarians my wife and I were happy to have found one. Our first impression of the place was...
review_full: On our first evening in Madrid, we tried Artemisa Huertas Cortes in Calle de Ventura de la Vega. Vegetarian restaurants in Madrid are rather scanty, so being vegetarians my wife and I were happy to have found one. Our first impression of the place was a little disappointing. The ambiance was rather prosaic. The restaurant consisted of a single rather long rectangular room with two rows of tables, those for two on the right, those for four on the left. The food, however, was of good quality and obviously attention had been paid to its appearance on the plate. To Madrilenian standards, the prices seemed reasonable. There is another Artemisa restaurant at Calle Tres Cruces, owned by the same company, as we found from their website when we were back home. The two should not be mixed up!

review_preview: An excellent vegetarian restaurant in the heart of Madrid. We ate twice there during August 2015. Interestingly we booked a table for 8.30pm the first night we were in Madrid.  We arrived promptly to find the restaurant still shuttered up (it doesn't open in the...
review_full: An excellent vegetarian restaurant in the heart of Madrid. We ate twice there during August 2015. Interestingly we booked a table for 8.30pm the first night we were in Madrid. We arrived promptly to find the restaurant still shuttered up (it doesn't open in the evening until 8.30pm). We had to wait about 10 minutes. The food was well worth the wait and the lady serving was friendly and helpful. We were the only diners. Interestingly when we left at about 9.45 there was still only one other couple and one single gentleman in the restaurant. We came back on our last night in Madrid and the experience was just as good - although there were two or three other people in the restaurant.  Overall the food is tasty, good variety and appetising; the service was good, the cost fine and the location excellent. Well worth a visit.

title_review: Good food but overall I felt deceived
review_preview: Due the good reviews, my bf and I went to Artemisa for dinner.The service was friendly and fast, but we were disappointed in a few things.We had a tasting menu for 2 (25,90 € VAT not included): moussaka, cous cous, escalibata with goat...
review_full: Due the good reviews, my bf and I went to Artemisa for dinner. The service was friendly and fast, but we were disappointed in a few things. We had a tasting menu for 2 (25,90 € VAT not included): moussaka, cous cous, escalibata with goat cheese, mushroom crepes and tofu sticks. The food was good, but it seemed quite overpriced not only because the main ingredients used were eggplants, onions and peppers, but also that we were served only 1 crepe, 1 slice of goat cheese and 4 small tofu sticks in total. Not a good idea if you are not having dinner with a close person. Furthermore we were charged for the unrequested bread brought to the table. Quite disappointing given that it wasn't clearly stated on the menu and it never happened in other restaurants.  The restaurant is cozy and has a lot of potential. More attention to the details mentioned above would make it a great place to go.

title_review: Best vegetarian lasagnas. You will leave with a tummy FULL!
review_preview: We thought at first sight the restaurant, hidden behind a curtain, was closed, thankfully it was not! I had there the best lasagnas ever, and the portion was absolutely huge! My husband took something "greek", not sure exactly of the name but it also came...
review_full: We thought at first sight the restaurant, hidden behind a curtain, was closed, thankfully it was not! I had there the best lasagnas ever, and the portion was absolutely huge! My husband took something "greek", not sure exactly of the name but it also came in huge proportions, so thank you!  My son drank a freshly pressed apple juice and it was fantastic (I admit I drank a bit of it too ;)). It add foam on top and was more like drinking an apple than just the average apple juice with sugar added. Just too good! I wish I knew how it was made. There is a down point which is that we, without notice, had to pay the bread they kept on the table. I'm not sure if it's a common thing done in Madrid or Spain though. We ate a part of it mostly while waiting for our main dish because we were just so hungry. Another down point is that we asked for tap water to save some money and our waitress who spoke perfect English (she probably was from UK according to her accent!) so I don't think she misunderstood but she served us a couple of bottles of water. I hate when that happens! I wish I had been brave enough to ask her to bring back the bottles and get us tap water but I wasn't. Our Spanish friends told us that it's common in restaurants to do this to sell more stuffs, too bad, that money could have been this waitress's tip but we ended up wasting it in bottled water!
