review_preview: A wonderful Sunday afternoon dinner with friends made even better thanks to a great restaurant and staff.  9 of us went for dinner here on Feb. 4, 2018 from 14:30 until 18:02.We were greeted with a pre meal drink, a screw driver basically, and...
review_full: A wonderful Sunday afternoon dinner with friends made even better thanks to a great restaurant and staff. 9 of us went for dinner here on Feb. 4, 2018 from 14:30 until 18:02. We were greeted with a pre meal drink, a screw driver basically, and then efficient and pleasant service. Meal was leisurely with none of us in a hurry. Service was efficient and always good natured though we all speak Spanish which helped. All of the food was great, we asked for Vino Honoro Vera Calatayud Garnacha 2014 but 2014 was sold out so we chose the 2016 which was excellent as was the price, 16E a bottle. 'Twas a very quiet and pleasant restaurant and we'll no doubt be back in early July of 2018 for wife's birthday. Do yourselves a favor and dine here, am sure you'll be back! Price for 9 of us was 323.00E including the hated IVA (sales tax) plus tip.

title_review: A Cheese Board and Mojito Experience
review_preview: We arrived late, underdressed and in a slightly bad mood, but the welcome was great and they really took care of us. They didn't mind that we wanted to order lots of little things (despite eagerly eyeing up the steaks that others were having). The...
review_full: We arrived late, underdressed and in a slightly bad mood, but the welcome was great and they really took care of us. They didn't mind that we wanted to order lots of little things (despite eagerly eyeing up the steaks that others were having). The service staff were wonderful and didn't randomly disappear for hours as they appear to do in most other places in Madrid. We ordered the cheese plate and were astonished at the amount of work that went into the preparation, then they created mojitos, which were much appreciated and then we started stealing each others food, as it was all so good. I felt guilty about the price so left a large-ish tip. This was hands-down the best place we ate in Madrid.

Spoke to us in English and apologised for not being better at speaking English. The fault is ours as we don’t speak Spanish.  The concept is great. It’s a set priced menu and you have a buffet type meal (salad, rice, potatoes, cous cous, tomatoes etc etc). Then a waiter comes round with various meats and cuts it off the skewer for you at the table. We had around 5/6 different meats and had the amazing grilled pineapple.  You have a small card which you leave on the green side for more meat or the red side for no more meat although the guys come round even when your card is red if it’s a type of meat you haven’t tried yet (great service in my eyes).  We shared a desert as we were so full and it was great.  Drinks are good too.  Like I say I wish we had found this gem a few nights ago.  Thank you and well recommended.

The service was excellent, all servers were very kind, polite and patient with our poor spoken Spanish. A delightful evening. Gracias!

title_review: Excellent. Much more than Tortilla. Where the locals go
review_preview: Deceptive street entrance - you barely notice it. You step into a simple room with white painted brick walls and a wood wine cellar at the end holding two more tables. It feels small but there is a second dining room the other side of...
review_full: Deceptive street entrance - you barely notice it. You step into a simple room with white painted brick walls and a wood wine cellar at the end holding two more tables. It feels small but there is a second dining room the other side of a small interior patio which is lighter and about the same side. Good atmosphere.  The menu is not huge but has a good variety of seafood and other options, and of course tortilla. I had two squid/squid cousin dishes, both cooked to perfection (succulent, tender) and with distinctive seasoning. Excellent wine by the glass. the plates are generous and this is definitely a place to share and to take your time. Excellent attentive service. This is the original restaurant of a small family business with two others called La Ancha, also very good. It is popular so book to avoid disappointment. My second visit. Easily matched my memory of the first time.

title_review: Couldn't have asked for better service
review_preview: I'll start by saying this was a fantastic experience from start to finish. So much so that I was compelled to write my first review for this little gem. I booked dinner going for the full rodizio option.We arrived early but this was no...
review_full: I'll start by saying this was a fantastic experience from start to finish. So much so that I was compelled to write my first review for this little gem.  I booked dinner going for the full rodizio option. We arrived early but this was no problem, we were welcomed very courteously by the staff. We were asked if we'd been to a rodizio before and the waiter patiently and comprehensively explained to us how it works.  We weren't sure about what wines to go for, and again without any hesitation the waiter went above and beyond and brought two bottles for us to try. On to the rodizio itself, firstly we started by getting our salads from the extensive buffet.  Here I would have preferred if the various options were described in a bit more detail as for most we just had to guess what they were. I guess in a way it helps to push you to try new dishes.  After a bit of snacking on the various buffet selections, the chef came over with the first meat serving. He was a very charming and sociable guy; even if he didn't speak english we had no issues getting served.  The quality of meat was absolutely fantastic, we both enjoyed the numerous cuts very much and it was clear this place did not cut any corners with their meat.  The meats were on a rotation so we sampled all of the options. At the end we were also served roasted pineapple with cinnamon which was also fantastic and obviously we had to ask for another portion which was promptly brought over.  The venue was clean, nicely decorated and the music selection was also very appropriate.    All in all it was one of the best decisions we made in our trip to have dinner here and if returning to Madrid, I will definitely come back here.  Keep up the good work! Viva rodizio en Vila Brasil!

title_review: Brilliant service, coffee, churros, porras and, of course, chocolat!
review_preview: Read some brilliant review last about this place and thought we would give it a go for our first breakfast of a short break in Madrid - so glad we did!On a lovely little side street, this really cozy little place is a must....
review_full: Read some brilliant review last about this place and thought we would give it a go for our first breakfast of a short break in Madrid - so glad we did! On a lovely little side street, this really cozy little place is a must. It’s not as swanky as some other places we tried but we thought it was the best for breakfast. And had the best churros and porras (think fatter churros!) than anywhere we went. Same with the chocolate which was thick and not too sweet. It was also packed full of locals so that, to me, is a great sign and is not so much full of tourists and on the tourist circuit. We also tried the toast and tomato too which was perfect! Great coffee as well. Fantastic service too so couldn’t ask for any more.

title_review: A cute spot with great chocolate
review_preview: I enjoyed coming here for chocolate and churros. The chocolate is thick and not too sweet - just as it should be. They offer porras (which are fried dough, like churros, but have more leavening so they're larger and airier) and regular churros. In addition,...
review_full: I enjoyed coming here for chocolate and churros. The chocolate is thick and not too sweet - just as it should be. They offer porras (which are fried dough, like churros, but have more leavening so they're larger and airier) and regular churros. In addition, they have a menu with meals and desserts - we also tried a couple desserts, which were good, but the churros and chocolate were our favorite. The staff are also very friendly and made us feel welcome. I'd highly recommend it!

title_review: Best meal on our trip to Madrid
review_preview: We had a fantastic night here, the food was good - not amazing but it was the whole experience that made our night.  We sat down and were immediately given a glass of sparkling rose cava and throughout the evening we were given lots of...
review_full: We had a fantastic night here, the food was good - not amazing but it was the whole experience that made our night. We sat down and were immediately given a glass of sparkling rose cava and throughout the evening we were given lots of other little extras that just made the evening special. The setting was lovely, we were outside looking onto the square with all the comings and goings, heaters and wraps - really cozy. We ordered and were brought a small portion of soup over, a bit like an amuse bouche, lovely! Our meals were all lovely and although we couldn't manage a dessert each we shared a dulce de leche crepe - delicious! We were also given a champagne sorbet each - amazing and a small portion of a panna cotta type dessert each. We were then dreading getting the bill given all of these extras but it was no more expensive than other places we'd eaten at this week. A lovely evening would definitely visit again.

title_review: Exceptional little restaurant at a great value
review_preview: La Tortilla de Gambino was a great find.  It is small, intimate restaurant.  We ordered croquettes and artichokes with Harmon for appetizers.  They were delicious.  For my entree, we ordered one of Spain’s national dishes - tortilla de potata for the first time.  We loved...
review_full: La Tortilla de Gambino was a great find. It is small, intimate restaurant. We ordered croquettes and artichokes with Harmon for appetizers. They were delicious. For my entree, we ordered one of Spain’s national dishes - tortilla de potata for the first time. We loved it. The service and food were outstanding. What surprised me most was how reasonably priced this meal. If I return to Madrid, this restaurant will be at the top of my list.

review_preview: The café "El Bocado de Carole" is a cute little café near Gran Vía. The owner is a really nice and always caring French woman with magic fingers making one of the best- if not the best- cakes, biscuits and other sweets I have ever...
review_full: The café "El Bocado de Carole" is a cute little café near Gran Vía. The owner is a really nice and always caring French woman with magic fingers making one of the best- if not the best- cakes, biscuits and other sweets I have ever eaten in my entire life! As it is a french café you of course can breakfast croissants and crepes. Also just delicious. The best about this place though is, that its not expensive at all. I´m not saying its super cheap, but absolutely affordable for students. As I am one I can tell. When I discovered this cute little place with two spanish friends we instantly fell in love with its heartily welcoming owner, the delicious offer, the calm atmosphere and the touch of France, as you can hear french radio and in the back of the café find a picture of the Eiffel Tour on the wall. The Chocolate Fondue- Oh my God!!!!!! You really need to go there! - I tried that day and all the other things we ordered made us call the place "El cielo" which translated means "heaven". Just to give you an example of HOW good it actually was! ;)  To cut it short now, if you want to visit a really nice, cheap and absolutely delicious café in Madrid- for breakfast, coffee time or whatsoever- got to "El Bocado de Carole"! Its not just worth a visit, but a Must! :) :*

title_review: It was nice enough- lacking imagination sometimes. Bit boring.
review_preview: I want to start with the positives: our waitress was genuinely FRIENDLY and gave good service and advice. The place was nice, very family-run like. You can tell the ingredients are FRESH and a good percent of them are ORGANIC . That's something to shout...
review_full: I want to start with the positives: our waitress was genuinely FRIENDLY and gave good service and advice. The place was nice, very family-run like. You can tell the ingredients are FRESH and a good percent of them are ORGANIC . That's something to shout out. The house wine I ordered was absolutely delicious as well. The BREAD was very artisan and we loved the taste. I think the fresh organic ingredients worth the maybe slightly higher price tag on some of the dishes. I would not say it was overpriced. For STARTER I ordered vegetable croquettes -they were really filling and delicious. My partner ordered nachos with guacamole. I don't particularly like guacamole but this was really nice! Plus point.  HOWEVER!- we both felt a bit disappointed by the lack of imagination on the menu. Most of the dishes had almost exactly the same ingredients!! As my boyfriend does not eat eggplants and courgette it was actually challenging to find a main course for him. Even I had an issue ordering something interesting . In the end we ordered a sharing platter. It had a vegetable paella that was okey, the above mentioned nice croquettes, some ratatouille like dish which was nice enough but overall a bit too average and eggplants and something else I cannot recall . Overall it was a bit boring. Without the starters I would have gone hungry. I would like to point out that WE ARE NOT vegetarian. I think if you are, or if you are after genuine, fresh , healthy food :this could be the place for you. Just do not put your hopes up about the variety.

review_preview: I was encouraged to go by the good reviews on TripAdvisor, so I went on a Tuesday night all by myself. At 20,30 the restaurant was still empty, which is normal in Spain. Although I speak Spanish a bit I asked for the English menu....
review_full: I was encouraged to go by the good reviews on TripAdvisor, so I went on a Tuesday night all by myself. At 20,30 the restaurant was still empty, which is normal in Spain. Although I speak Spanish a bit I asked for the English menu. The girl at the reception was very gentle but absolutely disinterested in her job. She stayed all the time chatting on her phone. I decided to order a vegan salad, which was a mixture of different vegetables (tomatoes, cucumbers, sweetcorn, green salad, olives, carrots, barbabietolas. The dish was big and good. As entrée I ordered the vegetarian wok: soy noodles with fried vegetables. This was a bit disappointing as the ingredients seemed not to be cooked at the same time. It was this mountain of needles and vegetables on top but the fry flavour was too strong and I didn't like it much. I drank a small bottled beer. All for 31 euros. At 21,30 I still was the only guest in the restaurant. The ambience was average. Nothing special. The lights too low. I think prices were quite high.

title_review: Yum, yum, yum...with a side of yum!
review_preview: We found this restaurant while searching out veggie options. Came in at lunchtime and barely beat the crowd. It was packed. Despite the business we received great service. Unfortunately the special, which seemed to be a good deal, was only available in Spanish. But the...
review_full: We found this restaurant while searching out veggie options. Came in at lunchtime and barely beat the crowd. It was packed. Despite the business we received great service. Unfortunately the special, which seemed to be a good deal, was only available in Spanish. But the regular menu was all in English and have plenty of delicious options, mid priced. We shared the salad for two which was amazing, fresh and well presented. I had the pasta with pear and cheese stuffed into it in a pesto sauce and it was amazing. Truly five-star dining. I will go back again a few times before I go home. You must try it!

What appeared was a mushy pile of indistinguishable ingredients with a solid topping of cheese and a pile of rather mushy vegetables on the side, not mentioned on the menu--a most unappetizing presentation. In addition, we were charged for bread they brought us that we didn't order. The only saving grace was that when we made comment on the bread charge and the clearly inedible meal (barely any was eaten), they took them off our bill.

review_preview: Before getting there, my girlfriend and I were really excited to try out the food, since we had heard about it on a Vegetarian Group on Facebook. We got there, and had to wait a little for a table to clear (no problem). We waited...
review_full: Before getting there, my girlfriend and I were really excited to try out the food, since we had heard about it on a Vegetarian Group on Facebook. We got there, and had to wait a little for a table to clear (no problem). We waited a good while for the waiter to take our order, and ordered right when he got there. Now on to the food, as I said, we were really excited, and once we got the food, it seemed delicious. However, first bite into it, and you could tell right away it was bland, mushy, and just terrible. Since we paid a lot of money for it, we weren't going to completely ruin the moment, but every bite was a bigger struggle than the last. Finally, towards the end, when I asked the waiter how the food was made, he was rude in telling me the following: Well, the food is made with rice, beans, you know, easy things. Wanting to get out of there as soon as possible, we went up to the Door Host, and told him of our opinion. He completely denied our claims that the food was bad, and that it seemed frozen, and simply put n a microwave.  If you're looking for good food, do yourself a favor and don't go here.

title_review: Good, but not ready for a Michelin Star
review_preview: My husband and I ate at this restaurant in September, 2018.  The ambience is quite nice.  The waiter recommended an excellent Ribera del Duero wine, namely the Alonso del Yerro 2008.  For our first course we split the pulpo a la brasa (grilled octopus) which...
review_full: My husband and I ate at this restaurant in September, 2018. The ambience is quite nice. The waiter recommended an excellent Ribera del Duero wine, namely the Alonso del Yerro 2008. For our first course we split the pulpo a la brasa (grilled octopus) which was beautifully presented and delicious. Next we split the "T bone de Ternera" (Veal T-bone steak) which was cooked exactly to our liking and seasoned perfectly with a light amount of salt. What for us keeps this restaurant from achieving Michelin Star status is the service level. At a fine dining restaurant the bread crumbs on the table should be promptly swept off the table by the waiter, and in the present case they were not, at least not until the end of the meal. Also, after the first glasses of wine and bottled water were poured by the waiter, we had to pour our own the rest of the evening. If Membibre can upgrade the service level they might be ready for a Michelin Star.

review_preview: Great sommelier, decent service (kind but with lack of attention), good food but significantly overpriced.- They have a nice list of wines and a great sommelier that gives perfect recommendations. - Service: numerous and kind staff at your service  but unorganised. - Food: poor...
review_full: Great sommelier, decent service (kind but with lack of attention), good food but significantly overpriced. - They have a nice list of wines and a great sommelier that gives perfect recommendations.  - Service: numerous and kind staff at your service but unorganised.  - Food: poor quality fish (and poorly cooked), great meat quality and preparation. - Price: clearly the downside. Even tough the service and some dishes were good, the price is absolutely out of scale. 16€ for a tiny cooked spring onion and 30€ for a steak tartare are just an example, as they are way too expensive considering the offer Madrid has.  In conclusion, good for a romantic dinner but we will not repeat since there are much better (and even cheaper) options in Madrid.

review_full: Listed in the Top 11 Restaurants on Eater We took a chance because the reviews were good but the pictures didn’t match. Don’t let the basic no nonsense decor fool you. This restaurant has been around since the 1960’s and the chef-founder has handed it down to his chef-son, and now to his chef-grandson in the early 20’s who has catches the attention of foodies and critics. They know what they are doing. Food was delicious! The service excellent. Loved the uniforms. The homemade butter trio served at the start was new to us: olive, spinach, and smoked. Excellent sourdough bread. Try: Octopus with mash potato Calamari two ways: grilled and fried The quail  The rack of baby lamb (never seen this dish before - amazingly tender) Good selection of cheeses. You can order one slice - even if it’s not offered in the menu.

review_preview: We just had an amazing dinner at this incredible restaurant. The terrace is located in a quiet street with very little traffic. Such a nice, enjoyable breeze. The service is michelin quality. Never did we have to call the waiter. Everything requested was answered with...
review_full: We just had an amazing dinner at this incredible restaurant. The terrace is located in a quiet street with very little traffic. Such a nice, enjoyable breeze.  The service is michelin quality. Never did we have to call the waiter. Everything requested was answered with a yes. And a smile. And the food: so much attention to detail, such meticulous presentation and timing between plates. The ‘small cuisine menu’ is really great value. You get such a variety of different tastes and aromas. Just wonderful. And yes, cheap. Quality/price here is unbeatable.  The beers were cold as was the white wine, always served in abundance and very well priced.  The elegance of the staff, the chef’s presence in the restaurant as well as the glamour and politeness of the madrileñan patrons of this restaurant all add up to a beautiful experience which will leave you a great aftertaste, even after receiving the bill. Dont miss out. Plan a dinner in Membibre.

title_review: For Chocolate & Churros, Look No Further
review_preview: This little shop tucked two blocks away from the Anton Martin metro shop serves the best chocolate con churros that I have ever had, anywhere.  The chocolate is thick and rich with the flavor of actual chocolate, and the churros come to your table fresh...
review_full: This little shop tucked two blocks away from the Anton Martin metro shop serves the best chocolate con churros that I have ever had, anywhere. The chocolate is thick and rich with the flavor of actual chocolate, and the churros come to your table fresh from the fryer. They have abunch of varieties of ways to enjoy the chocolate, but I can't comment on them - I would not be able to bring myself to pass by the plain chocolate drink. It's the perfect thing to have on a cold day or night. If you've been to San Gines, and think you understand chocolate con churros, come here and think again. You will be impressed.

title_review: When you tire of rude, curt waiters
review_preview: We walked into this place en route to the Sofia museum on our third day in Madrid.  We've had some great food here, but for the most part the service has not been something to write home about. We were accordingly pleasantly surprised by the...
review_full: We walked into this place en route to the Sofia museum on our third day in Madrid. We've had some great food here, but for the most part the service has not been something to write home about. We were accordingly pleasantly surprised by the warmth and good cheer of the staff at this small, budget eatery. What nice people! Food-wise, this isn't the best we'd had, nor the worst. Simple fare prepared in a workman-like way, I would describe it. Wine: above-average, but you get only a glass with the menu del dia, not the typical bottle or decanter. The included dessert--a tart with dark chocolate sauce--was perhaps the highlight of the meal, which came in at a comfortable 9.50 euros. We were then offered coffee, which came with a complimentary sweet, which we picked from a basket the waiter brought to our table, again with the best of cheer and perfect courtesy. All in all, a good value for a mid-day meal in Madrid.

And then there are brilliant little places like Chocolat, which offers pretty much perfect chocolate, not excessively sweet or gloopy, and churros which are hot and crispy. There are other items to be had, but why would anyone look further than chocolat con churros ? The staff are never short of a smile, seeming to be happy in their work. Worth the detour, for sure.

title_review: Looking for the best tortilla de patata in Madrid
review_preview: I am on a mission to find the best tortilla de patata in Madrid and provide an unbiased review about the bars and restaurants that serve them. I have been to Sylkar, El Meson de la Tortilla de Gabino, Juana la Loca, and Bodega de...
review_full: I am on a mission to find the best tortilla de patata in Madrid and provide an unbiased review about the bars and restaurants that serve them. I have been to Sylkar, El Meson de la Tortilla de Gabino, Juana la Loca, and Bodega de La Ardosa, and Cerveriz and tried their regular tortilla de patata. This was probably my 2nd favorite tortilla de patata that I tried. It was so rich and delicious with just the right amount of salt. From what I understood from our waiter (someone correct me if I'm wrong), their regular tortilla uses only egg yolks, which would explain why it was so creamy and rich. The potatoes were just right and there are no onions in this one, giving it a pure egg and potato taste. This was a tortilla that you have to share with someone, as this restaurant does not serve tapa/pincho style slices and you have to buy a whole (but small) tortilla instead, so it's not recommendable to come here alone. It's also important to note that this was the most expensive tortilla on my list, coming in at almost ten euros for one to share.

title_review: Excellent food, great service from chef/owner
review_preview: I visited this restaurant on July 12, 2014 with 5 others. We spotted it in a Michelin guide. The style of the restaurant is relaxed and casual. our reservation was early for Madrid (9pm) - we were the only ones there; by 10pm it was...
review_full: I visited this restaurant on July 12, 2014 with 5 others. We spotted it in a Michelin guide. The style of the restaurant is relaxed and casual. our reservation was early for Madrid (9pm) - we were the only ones there; by 10pm it was full. The food is delicious - they have a selection of starters, tortills and then fish and meats. We had a few dishes from each section all of which excelled. The chef owner trained in London and spent lots of time taking us through the menu in english as none of us spoke decent Spanish; he made a number of recommendations (including when to stop ordering!). We started with a rose Moet (44 euro); most wines on the menu are Spanish of course and very reasonably priced (the most expensive was 12 euro). The ham croquettes, jamon itself and the traditional and truffle tortillas were all delicious. Could not recommend this spot more. The owner has a couple of other places - at least one tapas place in Madrid and a spot in Athens (I think they're on the restaurant site). Definitely worth a visit.

review_preview: We visited this restaraunt during our visit to Madrid in May 2014. 2 adults and one 9 year old child. As it is stated in the name, specialities of restaraunt are traditional spanish Omlettes and they have variety of choice there. We decided to try...

As it is stated in the name, specialities of restaraunt are traditional spanish Omlettes and they have variety of choice there. We decided to try to differrent omlettes and both of them were good (Tortilla de Pulpo - yammi !). Child goes for Hamon set as a starter and liked it as well. As a main course we go for Iberia Ham, traditional antrecote and Hake - we all were quite happy of our choice. We tried different desserts as well, local Torrija was just normal one and natural yoghurt ice cream was very nice. Totally with bottle of wine, beer, water, cafe and tea for dessert it cost us around 150 Euro. Not a cheap one, but food was really good. I would recommend it as a choice for ones who would like to go for some local food. It is better to book in advance and keep in mind that majority of staff don't speak english.

review_preview: While within walking distance of the Sorolla Museum, a charming and underrated museum, this is a restaurant you almost certainly wouldn't  ever get to without advice from a local, and that was how my wife and I ended up there.  While we had spent a...
review_full: While within walking distance of the Sorolla Museum, a charming and underrated museum, this is a restaurant you almost certainly wouldn't ever get to without advice from a local, and that was how my wife and I ended up there. While we had spent a month in Barcelona, many of the items on this menu were new to us. Going with two couples had the great advantage that, if you decide, as we did , to share dishes, you get to taste more items. We had three appetizers and two main dishes, one fish and one meat. . The three appetizers we had were: croquetas de boletus (mushroom), ensaladilla russa con cigalas (baby lobster potato salad), and tortilla de espinatas con gambas (spinach and shrimp). . (NOTE: a Spanish tortilla is not a flour or corn crepe but more like a quiche or omelet.) The, two main dishes were delicias de merluza rebozadas (like a breaded haddock), and presa Iberico a la plancha (a grilled shoulder cut of pork). To finish off, we split two desserts:. helado de yogur con crema de higos naturales (yogurt with “natural” fig sauce and ice cream) and torrija con helado de limon (like a milky french toast with a sugary crème brulee crust). I loved everything but the mushroom croquettes (though my wife was a lot more positive about those), but I especially enjoyed the lobster potato salad, the melt in your mouth merluza, whose super light breading was as unlike American style fish sticks as it is possible to get, and the pork dish. Indeed, the lobster potato salad was, perhaps not surprisingly, the best potato salad I’ve ever eaten. The ambiance at this place was elegant without being pretentious, and the service was excellent. Because we had shared dishes, the bill came to well under 30 euros per person and we walked away very filled without having overeaten. Moreover, we could actually talk to each other rather than being blasted by American inspired pop music as in too many places. And we spent 2 hours over lunch without ever feeling rushed. My wife and I really hope to eat here again when we are next in Madrid. P.S. Reservations strongly suggested.

title_review: AMAZING AND AUTHENTIC!! A real gem!
review_preview: We stayed within a 5 minute walking distance to this restaurant and only found it by googling restaurants near our hotel.  So happy we stayed where we did or we may have missed this gem.  Our hotel concierge made our reservation for us at 9:15pm...
review_full: We stayed within a 5 minute walking distance to this restaurant and only found it by googling restaurants near our hotel. So happy we stayed where we did or we may have missed this gem. Our hotel concierge made our reservation for us at 9:15pm (opens at 9) and when we arrived we were pleasantly surprised by the very modern look of the restaurant. Our waiter didn't speak a lot of English but the Manager did and so he came over and asked us what foods we didn't like and then asked if he could simply just bring us food that he thought we should try. We said YES! It was AWESOME!!! We had several tapas courses (fried cheese balls, fried cherry tomato, razor clams, seafood with peppers, Spanish omelette, and we shared an entre of sea bass. Everything was DELISH! WE had a bread pudding type dessert (more like baked French toast) with a scoop of gelato on top. AMAZING MEAL!

review_preview: We were staying within walking distance of this gem and made a reservation on-line. The restaurant opens at 9pm and by 9:15pm every seat was taken. We tried to look at them menu on-line but it is in Spanish only. When we sat down, we...
review_full: We were staying within walking distance of this gem and made a reservation on-line. The restaurant opens at 9pm and by 9:15pm every seat was taken. We tried to look at them menu on-line but it is in Spanish only. When we sat down, we ordered a bottle if wine and asked if there may be an English version of the menu. With none available, we struggled a little to understand all the dishes until our waiter asked us how hungry we were and if he could go ahead and put together a dinner for us. He assured us, that if we were served something that was not to our liking he would replace it. We said "Muy Bueno" and let the games begin. The food came out at a good pace and each item was very tasty and presented beautifully. In some cases, the food was served from the cooking pan right to our plate at the table by several different servers coming out of the kitchen. Everything was wonderful and absolutely delicious. We had two small intro appetizers that were very good(julienned green bean dish and second, a Foie Gras Bon-Bon). Great start. Later plates included: Tortilla Valazquena(Potato) , Presa Iberica (Pork). Each of the plates for two were served perfectly and were sized appropriately. Two delicious desserts: Tartar de Frutas con arroz con leche(chilled rice pudding over finely chopped fruits) and a Postre Goloso De Chocolate (Choc Ice cream floating a frothy warm choc mousse). The staff was very attentive and helpful. Quality vs. value was extremely high. We drank two 12 year old bottles of wine and had all this great food for around 100 euros. What a wonderful night.

title_review: Omelettes are great but the marrow was the star
review_preview: Ambience is cozy and moderne with wood and exposed bricks. Service very attentive. The tables have central leg so no problems to join a couple for a large group. Tableware is nice but the glasses specially wine cups are too thick. They have an extensive...
review_full: Ambience is cozy and moderne with wood and exposed bricks. Service very attentive. The tables have central leg so no problems to join a couple for a large group. Tableware is nice but the glasses specially wine cups are too thick. They have an extensive well selected wine list. One of the maitres is a wine expert, ask him, is recommendations have always been great and not expensive. Dish presentation is nice. The omelettes are the main dish so the menu is divided in before and after the omelettes. Before you will find fried anchovies with a twist, octopus, razor shells/clams with a sauce and the star: the marrow served with a cream and caramelized with a small kitchen blowtorch. Omelettes are great in all fashions, for us the truffle omelette is king. The omelette style is a little bit undercooked (not a failure, that is the style). After the omelettes you find the usual meats, fish (we never get there...). Deserts are also nice specially the "torrija" (a kind of french toast).

title_review: Treated us very poorly! Stay away!

Then a party of 5 came in and they gave the table to the new party. We watched them enjoy churros & chocolate while still waiting. We were then offered 2 tables of 2 while my four year was asking why they did not want to give him any chocolate. No chocolate will ever be good enough to take the sour taste left by how badly we were treated....if there is a line, walk away... The whole experience ruined Madrid for us....oh yeah...they also did not bring us churros with our chocolate. We had to ask for it half way thru after other tables got theirs.  I am curious to see how the owner responds because this is exactly how the events unfolded. I did not exaggerate.

review_full: This is a restaurant, located in the centre of Madrid although outside the tourist areas of the town. Membibre has been runing for more than 40 years by the same family, and they propose a simple, traditional sapnish cuisine that nevertheless is of a very high standards.  Their aims seems to provide the freshest fish and meat available in the area, this is one of the very few restaurants still having a cold fridge as a store front, where you can see form the street the catch of the day on display. Choose it, pick it and they will cook it for you. All in all is avery nice place, not the cheapest one around but good value for money, if pressed for time, at lunch time on weekdays, there is a rotating daily menu, 2 courses plus dessert or coffee at very good prices.

review_preview: This tiny cafe is in a beautiful neighborhood between the Prado and the Plaza Mayor. We ate there twice in two days, it was that good. Hands down, the best Spanish-style hot chocolate I've ever had (after 5 trips to that country). The churros were...
review_full: This tiny cafe is in a beautiful neighborhood between the Prado and the Plaza Mayor. We ate there twice in two days, it was that good. Hands down, the best Spanish-style hot chocolate I've ever had (after 5 trips to that country). The churros were fresh and hot, but what really got our attention are these pastries called Lazos. I think they are the best pastry I've eaten - soft and sweet and moist and delicious. The coffee was good too. They offer some more substantial items like bocadillos, but I didn't try them. The service was excellent (and easy on the eyes, too).

title_review: Amazing authentic tortilla in this restaurant off the tourist track
review_preview: This tortilla restaurant has been the best restaurant by far. The tortilla with the deep fried green peppers and ewe's cheese is divine and melts in your mouth. One tortilla is more than enough for two people and is incredibly filling. Usually to be accompanied...
review_full: This tortilla restaurant has been the best restaurant by far. The tortilla with the deep fried green peppers and ewe's cheese is divine and melts in your mouth. One tortilla is more than enough for two people and is incredibly filling. Usually to be accompanied by delicious beef tomatoes dressed in parmesan and balsalmic vinegar. They also have amazing croquetas, some of the best I have savoured here in Madrid. I have yet to try the other dishes on the menu but this restaurant is usually busy and filled with well to do families or business men. Prices are a little steep for food but it is definitely worth it! A tortilla starts at around 11 euros, other dishes vary from 9 - 15 euros. There is a huge selection of tortillas that you can choose from. It works out as approximately 25 euros - 30 euros per person including wine. The staff are friendly and speak English, there is also an English menu. It is advisable to book a table! This restaurant is definitely authentic and Spanish and is off the beaten tourist track, tucked in on a side street. It is full of locals who know the restaurant by reputation. Fed up with the run of the mill tortillas made from heuvina (synthetic egg replacement) when out and about in Madrid I can't recommend it enough. Great for couples and romantic dinners.

title_review: Local and good value for Madrid
review_preview: Not ideal if you want "international comfort food", so a very good reason to come here!  Food very good - regional but not so obscure as to be unnerving...One of the staff spoke good English which is great because our Spanish is limited to poor....
review_full: Not ideal if you want "international comfort food", so a very good reason to come here! Food very good - regional but not so obscure as to be unnerving...One of the staff spoke good English which is great because our Spanish is limited to poor. Highly recommend the croquetas de boletus if you like mushrooms - like liquid creamy mushroom silky potato heaven in a crusty shell mmm... Fish of the day lovely and fresh. Great side dish of green veg: leeks, asparagus, beans etc Wine list interesting, good value, and worth talking to the sommelier. We arrived for dinner at 8.30 and we were very early! Hugely popular with family groups and friends. (PS It was hidden behind scaffolding in Feb 13 but worth persisting to find it.)

title_review: Good Service But The Hype Is Unwarrated
review_preview: Decided to visit here for breakfast due to the many rave reviews.  Hmmmm....arrived around 10 to find the only foods that remotely resembled breakfast (scrambled eggs I think) wrapped tightly and placed in a small display case.  The menu I was given contained only foods...
review_full: Decided to visit here for breakfast due to the many rave reviews. Hmmmm....arrived around 10 to find the only foods that remotely resembled breakfast (scrambled eggs I think) wrapped tightly and placed in a small display case. The menu I was given contained only foods I associated with late Madrid dining (churros, hot chocolate). With no other available choices and not wanting to appear rude and walk out we ordered the churros and hot chocolate. Very greasy indeed. Both items.  The place was almost empty but as we were leaving a tour guide brought in a group of about nine older women. At that point I realized I had eaten right on a well worn tourist circuit. This wasn't the experience I had been looking for. The server was exceptionally nice and polite and offered us a free cookie. Maybe for an evening stop to enjoy a late night snack this place would be perfect. Otherwise I am not quite sure what else would draw an early diner in.

title_review: Wonderful spot for coffee and chocolate
review_preview: Located in the Letras barrio of Madrid, this café seems non-descript and ordinary from the outside. Once inside you realize you are in a special place. The waiters are courteous, the decor is hardly modernist chic, and the food is superb. We went for breakfast...
review_full: Located in the Letras barrio of Madrid, this café seems non-descript and ordinary from the outside. Once inside you realize you are in a special place. The waiters are courteous, the decor is hardly modernist chic, and the food is superb. We went for breakfast of churros, chocolate and coffee. The churros were freshly made and tasty. The chocolate, served in a little bowl, was rich and thick. My friend ordered coffee, and she was not disappointed. The waiters were attentive, but did not hover. The activity was constant. We were surprised by the cost relative to the high qualty of our churros. While this spot may lack the historic character assiated with other Chocolaterías in Madrid, it has the feel of neighborhood spot with excellent attention to the quality of their churros and service. The café is worth a visit for the churros experience.

title_review: Authentic Spanish culinary experience with no fuss
review_preview: It's hard to find a good quality restaurant in Madrid without being conned into the trap of touristic spot! Membibre is defo worth your time especially if you only have a short stay. It's a short distance from the main hub but within walking distance...
review_full: It's hard to find a good quality restaurant in Madrid without being conned into the trap of touristic spot! Membibre is defo worth your time especially if you only have a short stay. It's a short distance from the main hub but within walking distance or a cab ride. The diners are all local and they don't have an English menu - a positive sign for us. Waiters are all professional with efficient service. We loved the food served - from amuse bouche to starters (croquette and blood sausage) to mains (fish and quail!!) - the portion was v generous so be careful! Highly recommended

review_preview: I have to say, I'm surprised by the somewhat up and down reviews.  For me, this was one of the best places I've eaten at in a very long time.  The food was outstanding and perfectly prepared. The atmosphere was nice, quaint, though perhaps a...
review_full: I have to say, I'm surprised by the somewhat up and down reviews. For me, this was one of the best places I've eaten at in a very long time. The food was outstanding and perfectly prepared. The atmosphere was nice, quaint, though perhaps a little plain. For me, I think the disconnect is around the menu itself. This is a very traditional Spanish menu with a nice touch of elegant flair...and cooked to absolute perfection. I will add that we also ate at Pan Lugo (very fancy upscale dining) and we preferred this place for a better, more comfortable dining experience. If you are on vacation and looking for an excellent Spanish dining experience, you will do no better than this place. Enjoy (and order the flan for dessert!)

title_review: Chocolat is the place for breakfast when in Madrid.
review_preview: My husband and I visited Madrid in both May and October 2011.  We ate breakfast everyday at Chocolat (totaling nearly two weeks over the course of our two visits).  The food is great and the staff very friendly.  More than that, though, is the fact...
review_full: My husband and I visited Madrid in both May and October 2011. We ate breakfast everyday at Chocolat (totaling nearly two weeks over the course of our two visits). The food is great and the staff very friendly. More than that, though, is the fact that we would see the same locals every day, which really made for a lively atmosphere. I'll never eat breakfast anywhere else when I'm in Madrid. We've been back for only a week and I really miss Alphonso, the owner, and his team.

title_review: Great for churros and hot chocolate
review_preview: This is a lovely little place to find and have churros and chocolate, or just a coffee, whether for breakfast or another time. It's not an obvious location, but you can wander through the pleasant little streets in the area until you find it. The...
review_full: This is a lovely little place to find and have churros and chocolate, or just a coffee, whether for breakfast or another time. It's not an obvious location, but you can wander through the pleasant little streets in the area until you find it. The staff are indeed nice and do offer you a free cookie/biscuit with your order! There also were a fair few locals (and not many tourists) just casually sipping/eating/chatting when I went with my friends, so that was nice. I had the churros y chocolate and the churros were lovely and fresh, not too oily, the chocolate thick and not overly sweet. My black coffee (cafe sólo) was strong and I liked it. My friend asked for an iced Americano and received the glass of ice separately to pour the coffee into, which was different but perfectly nice.

review_preview: Forget the BIG name chocolaterias with their long lines. Tucked away on a little back street just a 5 minute walk from the Anton Martin metro stop is Chocolat. The Chocolat is HUGE thick & rich, the churros fresh, hot & delicious!! It is a...
review_full: Forget the BIG name chocolaterias with their long lines. Tucked away on a little back street just a 5 minute walk from the Anton Martin metro stop is Chocolat. The Chocolat is HUGE thick & rich, the churros fresh, hot & delicious!! It is a small, friendly & very local place. Staff is courteous & truly delight in making you smile. This was my twins first trip to Madrid & first "Spanish" hot chocolate which is far different from the thin, pale stuff they are used to in the states. Spanish chocolate is thick,( much more pudding like- fit for dipping your churros) rich & far less sweet, DARK chocolate & FABULOUS. Always a favorite stop for me & now my girls know what to look for in churros & chocolate as all others will be measured against this! Chocolat...you have ruined them for life!! Job well done.

review_preview: I try to write good reviews and even changed my rating from terrible that I first put down to poor. So we saw their meal special, they did not have tables so we sat at the bar for over 20 minutes. Other places would have...
review_full: I try to write good reviews and even changed my rating from terrible that I first put down to poor. So we saw their meal special, they did not have tables so we sat at the bar for over 20 minutes. Other places would have sat you somewhere since there were open tables outside but it was for dinners a la cart This is 4 adults and 2 children under 5. Asked if we could just order at the bar and were told it would not be long. After over 20 minutes got a table. Asked if we could get our drink and only came back with 2. Asked another server and said they would get it still no drinks after some time asked again and we all got our drinks. By the time we sat down the special had increased by a Euro but by then we didn't care. So I order the empanada which was really good. The fries came next. Asked for ketchup none came. By then our rib came. Not much meat just hard gristle. My daughter ordered chicken which was a good choice. Finally got 3 ketchup packs for all four of us. Asked for extra and after 5 minutes got 3 more packs. We ordered the flan and ice cream which we liked. I speak Spanish so our issues were not due to the language. I felt they were not into tourist and spent their time catering to locals who were spending more on the white table cloth dinning area. Never going there again.

title_review: Best Tortilla Patatas we've ever had!
review_preview: I did some research before we traveled to Madrid so I knew there was a fair chance this was going to be as good as mentioned in some of the articles I read.  OMG!  These tortillas did not disappoint.  We went for two tortillas, Cheese...
review_full: I did some research before we traveled to Madrid so I knew there was a fair chance this was going to be as good as mentioned in some of the articles I read. OMG! These tortillas did not disappoint. We went for two tortillas, Cheese and pepper (not the name on the menu) and truffle. I don't even know how to convey into words the deliciousness, soft custardy interior, perfect seasoning, and perfectly cooked tortilla! We also had the veal cheeks which were just as good and again, possibly some of the best we've ever had. A bottle of wine, some bread and we were out of there for $90 USD (conv. of $1.17USD to 1 Euro at the time). We stayed near Plaza del Sol so we had to take a cab to and from but that was no problem. Staff were lovely and patient with our broken Spanish and did have some English language skills themselves (better than our Spanglish!). If you love tortillas this place is a MUST! Be sure to make reservations before going. We went on a Monday night at 9pm (they do not open the doors until exactly 9pm) and the restaurant was quickly full.

title_review: Great  meal near the Opera de Madrid
review_preview: My husband had the best steak of our entire four months in Spain.  Our meal started with a glass of sparkling wine, gift of the house.  Then the meal with tantalizing bits offered first.  The service was excellent.  When we declined dessert we were brought...
review_full: My husband had the best steak of our entire four months in Spain. Our meal started with a glass of sparkling wine, gift of the house. Then the meal with tantalizing bits offered first. The service was excellent. When we declined dessert we were brought a half pineapple filled with a delectable custard with fresh pineapple bits, followed by a little glass of a mango sorbise, and finally a glass of limoncello. All compliments of the house. We weren't sure whether these were in honor of an anniversary of the restaurant or usual, but we enjoyed them. We considered it 75 euros well spent.

review_preview: A small and discrete place, will woo you with multiple small dishes of mostly Spanish fare done in a delicate and sophisticated fashion.  You cannot leave the place without having the mollejas (sweetbreads), it is simply fantastic.  We had a fabulous experience with the waiter...
review_full: A small and discrete place, will woo you with multiple small dishes of mostly Spanish fare done in a delicate and sophisticated fashion. He appeared whenever we needed him, and provided great advice on dishes. The draft beer is very good, and we had a great red wine by the glass. After helping us to more food and drinks than we needed, it cost us about USD 35 per person. Worth every penny. I am surprised Michelin hasn't discovered this one yet. One macaron is more than deserved.

title_review: Surprisingly good and a chance find
review_preview: Opera is on a metro line and the stop nearest the Royal Palace (well worth a visit in its own right). Coming out of the Metro, we happened upon De Maria Opera and - looking more like a pukka restaurant - we ventured inside.  Ushered...
review_full: Opera is on a metro line and the stop nearest the Royal Palace (well worth a visit in its own right). Coming out of the Metro, we happened upon De Maria Opera and - looking more like a pukka restaurant - we ventured inside. Ushered upstairs, we had a table by the window looking onto the square. What separates this place out from others are the "extras" which accompany each meal: The pink "prosecco", the round toasts with cream cheese, and the small glass of carrot soup which precede each meal. To finish we had small glasses of yogurt with kiwi sauce on top, and followed by raspberry schnapps. Wonderful! As to my main course I had ravioli with mushrooms and a dessert of cheesetart. we washed everything down with a tempranillo. Very smooth. Total bill was €87 and we wondered how we could eat so well and cheaply in London! A place to return!

review_preview: Stumbled across this restaurant by chance, and it ended up being the highlight of our trip to Madrid! Amazing location and superb atmosphere; we ended up sitting outside despite it being mid-January with heaters and a blanket keeping us cosy and music from the plaza...
review_full: Stumbled across this restaurant by chance, and it ended up being the highlight of our trip to Madrid! Amazing location and superb atmosphere; we ended up sitting outside despite it being mid-January with heaters and a blanket keeping us cosy and music from the plaza giving an incredible vibe! The steak was absolutely delicious and perfectly cooked, probably the best steak i've had in my life - we ordered artichokes and some garlic fries to accompany this which were also very good. What really made this a treat however was the attentive staff and generous offerings; providing us with nibbles and drinks to begin without even asking and ending the meal with a mango parfait and lemon slush drink! Simply amazing in every sense! If you're ever in madrid, this is the place to go: perfect food, incredible atmosphere and first class hospitality!

The bread and service was Euro 2.30 each but considering what they gave you that was nothing, Overall the service was excellent and the food really good.

title_review: Nice environment, small dishes lacked flare
review_preview: Enjoyed dinner on a Saturday night after the theater. We dined in the tapas (more informal) area; there is also a salon for more elaborate meat and fish entres. Our four tapas and desserts were just OK; inventive yet lacking in flavor; service was rushed...
review_full: Enjoyed dinner on a Saturday night after the theater. We dined in the tapas (more informal) area; there is also a salon for more elaborate meat and fish entres. Our four tapas and desserts were just OK; inventive yet lacking in flavor; service was rushed at first and then disappeared entirely once things got busy. We arrived a bit early for drinks before the 9pm crowd rolled in. No fewer than 4 waiters kept asking if we were ready to order; good intentions but a bit pushy and interrupting always. We had four dishes: the sardine, croquetas, merluza, and grilled veges. Sardine was cold, bland. Croquetas were undercooked and too gooey. Merluza was an excellent fish -- delicate - cooked perfectly - but the limited cream sauce didn't do any favors. Grilled veges were probably the best, but they came out late and lukewarm. Vino tinto by the glass selection was limited to 2 options; Ribeira was excellent; the Rioja seemed cheap. Table bread was completely dry (yesterday's?). Best dish of the evening was the queso izarraitz wrapped in membrillo in the shape of cannelloni and a side of cinnamon ice cream - this was inventive and came together well. The service that was over-eager at the start of the meal was nowhere to be found, to ask for a coffee or the bill -- had to get the hostess's attention for the bill as they were too busy. The atmosphere is lively and good, but we other chose the wrong dishes or the kitchen afford to step up its game.

title_review: Great meal sitting out on the plaza Isabel
review_preview: We had a wonderful meal on our 1st night in Madrid at this restaurant on plaza Isabel, near Opera. Firstly we were given a glass of cava each on the house, followed by pumpkin soup - again, as tala as, on the house. The meals...
review_full: We had a wonderful meal on our 1st night in Madrid at this restaurant on plaza Isabel, near Opera. Firstly we were given a glass of cava each on the house, followed by pumpkin soup - again, as tala as, on the house. The meals do not come with veg so we foolishly ordered 2 portions s of Spanish potatoes - 1 would have been plenty. We sat outside under a patio heater and even on a February evening the temperature was fine. We were then given a dessert on the house, a mango smoothie and a kiwi mousse - all beautifully presented. Finally we were offered the liquor of the house too! The Seville e was excellent, not too rushed or too slow. We found another restaurant belonging to the same group so I guess they are a chain. If the others are s good as this one in Opera then definitely a good bet for a meal in Madrid.

We like the outdoor terrace, with heating and blankets in cooler weather, mist in hot weather... and appreciate the wheelchair accessible bathroom. They have a menu del dia, but I prefer the pasta on the ala carte menu. Good wine list. The restaurant sends out small complimentary appetizer and dessert as well as after dinner drinks. We had a family mother's day dinner here this year; all 7 of us were happy with our food and drinks. There are several locations, but this one is our favorite.

review_preview: My wife and I ate here on the last night of a recent short visit to Madrid. We chose it partly because of strong Trip Advisor reviews but also because it was no more than a 5 minute walk from our hotel and the weather...
review_full: My wife and I ate here on the last night of a recent short visit to Madrid. We chose it partly because of strong Trip Advisor reviews but also because it was no more than a 5 minute walk from our hotel and the weather was stormy. As other reviewers have mentioned, you get a generous amount of freebies here. A glass of cava when you arrive, and then a small cup of gazpacho plus a generous dollop of cream cheese and croutons as tasty amuse bouches. After dinner is over, there are complimentary bite size puddings (two each in our case) and a flask of something akin to limoncella is left with you to help yourself. The compulsory bread basket is priced at just over 2 euros, which seems very reasonable when you consider what else arrives for nothing! The portions of what you do pay for are big, so be warned. Either arrive very hungry, share a starter or a dessert between two people, or restrict yourselves (as we did) to just a main course each (plus a vegetable side dish in my case to accompany the lemon chicken). The serving staff were lovely, with good English spoken. The house white wine at around 11 euros per bottle was extremely tasty and highly recommended.

review_preview: We were tempted to go to another churrería because it was well known, but since we already know that just because one place is known for its food doesn't mean it's the best, we decided to look for alternatives and ended up finding this one...
review_full: We were tempted to go to another churrería because it was well known, but since we already know that just because one place is known for its food doesn't mean it's the best, we decided to look for alternatives and ended up finding this one on a random post somewhere on the internet. Given the reviews I found here, we decided we had to go there just after we arrived in Madrid to have a decent breakfast. The place is small, but very central (just take Paseo del Prado for a while and then take a left if you come from Atocha). The most amazing thing about that place... well, I'm still undecided, since the amazing service and the mouthwatering churros con chocolat are about even. When we got there, the place was empty, but soon it was really crowded with both tourists and locals, but that didn't stop the staff from greating everyone and offering some complimentary pastries and getting the food to everyone on time. About that food: we only tried the churros con chocolat, the Pakistani (or something resembling the word Pakistani) tea and the expresso, and all of them were amazing, even the expresso, which is actually hard to find around Spain. The churros were really tasty, crunchy with a soft center, not too oily and the portion was really large. The chocolat isn't too sweet, which I generally find a turnoff, but the cup was so big it ended up being the right amount of sweet and creamy goodness to dunk your churro.

review_preview: I visited this restaurant during a short stay in Madrid. I chose it for the location - Plazza Isabel II near the Opera. The Plazza had a buzz of energy and this looked welcoming for a lone traveller.I started with a huge health green...
review_full: I visited this restaurant during a short stay in Madrid. I chose it for the location - Plazza Isabel II near the Opera. The Plazza had a buzz of energy and this looked welcoming for a lone traveller. I started with a huge health green salad and the Ravioli which was the best I have had, all homemade with a delicious light pink sauce. Very tasty and just the right portion. The thing about this restaurant was their pride in their cuisine and they provided samples for all the guests. These included a complimentary glass of pink Cava, bread rounds and herbed butter, soup in a glass, sorbet, chocolate yoghurt and berries. The crème caramel at the end was homemade and just so yummy. All complimented with the local wine. This gave a great example of what is available and for a solo traveller this is great and it is impossible to sample tapas. The staff were very friendly and attentive. I would certainly recommend this restaurant whilst visiting Madrid. The total cost Euro 35.

title_review: Friendly staff, great atmosphere, great CHURROS.
review_preview: 'Chocolat' is a small typically Spanish cafe with a warm and friendly atmosphere. We went there late morning and it was not too busy, but had a steady stream of locals and regulars through the door. We ordered 'chocolate con churros' for two, and received...
review_full: 'Chocolat' is a small typically Spanish cafe with a warm and friendly atmosphere. We went there late morning and it was not too busy, but had a steady stream of locals and regulars through the door. We ordered 'chocolate con churros' for two, and received a good sized portion, the churros were not too greasy so didn't leave you with a heavy feeling. We were also offered a biscuit from a selection presented on a large tray at our table by one of the waiters, which was on the house. Very good value for money and a lovely start to the day. Wish we could make it our morning regular place, but will most certainly be back.

review_preview: We stumble into this restaurant around 1:30 PM in our way back from a visit to the Palacio Real. It was lunch time and extremely busy. As we were looking for a table the manager approached us and gave us choices for seating. We decided...
review_full: We stumble into this restaurant around 1:30 PM in our way back from a visit to the Palacio Real. It was lunch time and extremely busy. As we were looking for a table the manager approached us and gave us choices for seating. We decided for a table inside to stay away from smokers.  Even so the restaurant was packed within few minutes the waitress took our order of drinks and as soon as we put down the menus our order for food was taken. The lunch was excellent. With the drinks they brought us one “tapa” as well as two small bowls of pumpkin soup that was delicious. Our order was grilled to perfection. We took a light lunch but we were served additional things like a yogurt/fruit jam dessert, lemon sherbet and Lemoncello. While there we observed the different dishes being served and decided that we were going back for dinner to try some other of the tempting dishes they have. The dinner was as good as our lunch. We choose the 12.5 EU dinner that included (2) grilled meats, potatoes and salad as well as the drinks and dessert, including flan that was very good.  I would highly recommend this restaurant. The food is excellent and the service is timely, courteous and efficient. It is an Argentine owned restaurant so they know how to chose and grill their meats. It is very clean and the ambiance is very good. The floor manger (Angel) runs the place extremely well. One of the best choices in Madrid.

Wine not cheap, but the same price we would have paid in the UK.

review_preview: My friends and I spent a weekend in Madrid. On Friday we went for a late lunch in this restaurant and spent hours catching up over lovely food and cava. Prices are really reasonable and we found the portion sizes generous. We all had salads...
review_full: My friends and I spent a weekend in Madrid. On Friday we went for a late lunch in this restaurant and spent hours catching up over lovely food and cava. Prices are really reasonable and we found the portion sizes generous. We all had salads and side dishes and were really pleased with our choices. This is a chain of restaurants but in this particular one we were left for hours to catch up over bottles of cava, and our waiter didn't intrude but was very generous offering free additional glasses, along with some local drinks. We also all had dessert and again each was delicious. The bill was one of the most reasonable we had all weekend! Would gladly spend another afternoon here

review_preview: My sister and I were starving after a day of running around Madrid seeing the sights! We stumbled across this restaurant after getting off the Opera Metro. We quickly got a seat and ordered. I ordered a ribeye medium and the asparagus. When the meat...
review_full: My sister and I were starving after a day of running around Madrid seeing the sights! We stumbled across this restaurant after getting off the Opera Metro. We quickly got a seat and ordered. I ordered a ribeye medium and the asparagus. When the meat came out it was incredibly tough and was rare. I do not generally like to have my food taken back for fear of retribution, so I ate around the edges where the steak was less rare, but by no means medium. There was a large majority of the steak that I couldn't eat. My sister the braver of us, asked them to cook her steak longer. It was the worse cut of meat that I have tasted. I was so disappointed, especially since the restaurant is a little pricey. This was the worst meal that I have had in Madrid. The service was okay, and the only great thing about the meal was the asparagus. The asparagus were probably the best tasting that I have had and the reason this place did not get a rating of one. The waitress sensing our disappointment, brought us a type of mango drink at the end for free. I wanted so much to like the place, especially seeing all of the positive reviews. The atmosphere was nice, but the experience was a dud for me!

title_review: Dinner in  Madrid on New Year's Day
review_preview: Overall, the food was very good.  Vegetable options were prepared well. We enjoyed the beef steak, cooked as ordered, medium rare.    There were two disappointments in  our experience here.  Perhaps we should have known better, but when we sat down to read the menu, our...
review_full: Overall, the food was very good. Vegetable options were prepared well. We enjoyed the beef steak, cooked as ordered, medium rare. There were two disappointments in our experience here. Perhaps we should have known better, but when we sat down to read the menu, our waiter brought a basket of lovely bread and rolls, which we sampled, and enjoyed. When our bill arrived, we discovered that the bread and rolls were not complementary -- we were charged 6.60 euros. If we had known this, we would have passed on the bread. Secondly, as some other reviewers have mentioned, the service was not as attentive as we would expect for a restaurant in this category. It took a long time for our waiter to return to take our orders, bring us our drinks, and to bring the meals. His attitude was very "standoffish" We felt that he ignored us, even though the restaurant was not busy - such a difference from the experiences we had in every other restaurant we visited in Madrid. Our total bill, for 3 adults, including wine, was 111 Euros. I think if the service had been better, that amount might have been more acceptable.

review_preview: I walked past this restaurant a few times whilst I was in Madrid and it was always busy so thought it would be a great choice. I went by at lunch time to book a table and reserved a table for 2 at 7pm later...
review_full: I walked past this restaurant a few times whilst I was in Madrid and it was always busy so thought it would be a great choice. I went by at lunch time to book a table and reserved a table for 2 at 7pm later that night. The guy who took our reservation was lovely and very friendly and said it was no problem. When my mum and I arrived at 7pm we were greeted and seated in a back area, almost like private dining and we were the only people in that area, everyone else was in the front or outside. We just assumed that as the Spanish traditionally eat later at night, perhaps we were just a bit early. However, the service we experienced was awful. The girl who served us was downright horrible and gave us dirty looks from the minute we sat down. She was cleaning that area and would mop right at our feet hitting us with it and scowling at us. My mum was really upset and kept saying to me do you think we have done something wrong? are we not meant to be here? When she came over and took our order, she rolled her eyes every time we asked a question about the menu. She then walked away from us and we again felt like we'd done something wrong. When she brought our food out the plates were literally slammed on the table, it was so loud I felt really bad like i wasn't meant to be there. We were given complimentary appetisers and when we asked what they were as we really enjoyed them she just walked away from us. Her attitude and expressions towards us were horrible and we felt guilty for eating in the restaurant - like we were an inconvenience to her! After the main course, we had a different waiter tend to us who was really kind and explained the mango sorbet to us and told us facts about Madrid which lightened up our evening. we were going to order dessert but chose not to as my mum was scared this would anger the waitress even more. When we asked for the bill she chucked it on the table and walked off. It was a very disappointing experience and even more so because the food was great and the set up with all of the complimentary appetisers and after dinner snacks was fabulous! It could have been a great night but we were left feeling horrible and wished we'd never been so excited to visit. We couldn't get out of there fast enough. I wish it had been better but treating customers like that is really sad, i reiterate what i said previously in the fact that we felt like we were doing something wrong by eating there. Maybe we were just there too early, but if so our reservation shouldn't have been taken. I can't say I would recommend this to others as it was generally a disheartening and upsetting experience, especially for my mum.

review_preview: You get 5 things for €12.50 with the dinner menu. INCREDIBLE! The flavor was good - nothing to write home about. But for us broke young folks it's a steal! Appetizer, main course, side, dessert (cafe, ice cream, flan), and a drink (soft drink, wine,...
review_full: You get 5 things for €12.50 with the dinner menu. INCREDIBLE! The flavor was good - nothing to write home about. But for us broke young folks it's a steal! Appetizer, main course, side, dessert (cafe, ice cream, flan), and a drink (soft drink, wine, or beer). Also they brought plenty of good bread throughout the meal. Just note in Spain where you sit in the restaurant your food costs different prices. The same meal outside on the patio was €13.50, inside the meal with €12.50, same meal standing up at the bar was €10. Also, they just brought us each a free mini mango smoothie. I noticed they did that to other tables as well :) cool bonus for such a cheap price. Also the portion size of the ribs & chicken was actually big (for European standards, not American)

review_preview: Two of us dined for less than 40 euros in the plaza opposite the Theatro Real, which in any capital city would be a bargain. The quality of food was very high and the service excellent. There is no need to order an aperitif, starter...
review_full: Two of us dined for less than 40 euros in the plaza opposite the Theatro Real, which in any capital city would be a bargain. The quality of food was very high and the service excellent. There is no need to order an aperitif, starter or dessert. A glass of pink fizz, some crostini, a mango sorbet and half a jug of limoncello were complimentary. Leaving us only needing to order a main and some wine. Both of which were good quality and well-priced. The salads are enormous, and were hugely popular with most diners in being the height of summer, but we also saw a delicious steak being brought out and I expect that none of the food could be faulted, the menu was wide-ranging between salads, grills and nice looking pasta dishes. The restaurant also offers an incredible fixed price menu at 10 euro - for location, style and professionalism of the staff (as well more freebie nibbles/drinks than you can shake a stick at) it would be hard to beat. The restaurant also has cooling water sprays on the terrace to ensure the clientele stay cool. You would not get such quality elsewhere. Well worth it.

review_full: The place was really busy on that Friday night. A lot of friends and couples and solo players enjoying some nice tapas - religiously tuna-based - and good wine. Of course is not the best place if you are not a fish lover. If you are sitting long sides the corridor it might be annoying for the people and the waitress passing by, and also a nice local beer would be a nice add to the offering, but overall a cool place, with nice (fish) food, and tons of happy people. Icing on the cake it is located in one of the best streets of Madrid, with many other options for eating or drinking.

title_review: A restaurant that takes pride in what they do. Excellent service.
review_preview: I went with my family for dinner a couple of weeks ago. We ordered the garlic prawn croquetas which were amazing and then we ordered a number of things both from the menu and outside it. I was a little unlucky and I didn't particularly...
review_full: I went with my family for dinner a couple of weeks ago. We ordered the garlic prawn croquetas which were amazing and then we ordered a number of things both from the menu and outside it. I was a little unlucky and I didn't particularly like my choice, the false risotto, it just lacked flavour. When asked by the waiter, I gave him my honest opinion and he very kindly offered to change it for something else. I refused because i had filled up on their delicious bread. He didn't charge us for that dish and invited us to dessert which was not necessary but still appreciated. Everyone else loved their choices and the dessert was delicious.  Service likes this turns a mediocre experience into a really positive one. I will definitely be back.

review_preview: I am only writing this review because I am BIG on customer service!! My boyfriend and I were searching for a top restaurant to eat on our last day in Madrid. We found this location and were excited by the reviews. When we enter, I...
review_full: I am only writing this review because I am BIG on customer service!!  My boyfriend and I were searching for a top restaurant to eat on our last day in Madrid. We found this location and were excited by the reviews. When we enter, I greeted with a hello and immediately the bald guy behind the bar asked if we had reservations. He didn't care to acknowledge us. We said no but he sat us down. The place was not full at all.  I must say, the big bald guy was beyond the worse waiter, owner, what ever he was. I have never experienced such bad service.  First of all, the food is good. Try the shrimp croquets and the liquid croquets. DO NOT TRY THE STEAK ON SUSHI RICE, if you like your steak well done.  Second, the menu is so difficult to read. We asked the bald guy to explain some things and you can tell he was beyond annoyed from the moment we sat down. I felt him breathing down my neck. He definitely wanted us out.  Third, he came so fast with the receipt and threw it on the table. Once we paid, I kept saying thank you to him and making eye contact and so did my boyfriend but nothing. The cooks that were bringing the food out were actually nice and helped us out when we ordered our wine bottle.  The place is alright but I HIGHLY RECOMMEND to take your hard earn money elsewhere.

review_preview: What is not to love about this place?Been many times and it just keeps improving. They change the menu VERY CONSTANTLY and every new menu is great. Often you feel disappointed at first because the dishes you had the previous time had disappeared but...
review_full: What is not to love about this place? Been many times and it just keeps improving. They change the menu VERY CONSTANTLY and every new menu is great. Often you feel disappointed at first because the dishes you had the previous time had disappeared but the new dishes are always equally great. Service is friendly and polite yet I believe they could use a extra hand. It does feel as if the service is trying but at times they are just overwhelmed. They could really use an extra waiter (it would be more pleasant for both customers and employees). Just go and try as many Croquetas you can! Also, they serve great cocktails!
